div.p: THE Mistaken Husband. A COMEDIE, As it is Acted by His MAJESTIES SERVANTS At the Theatre-Royall. By a Person of Quality.
LONDON, Printed for I. Magnes and R. Bentley in Russel-street in Coven-Garden near the Piazza's, Anno Domini, MDCLXXV.

div.head: The Bookseller to the Reader.
div.p:
THis Play was left in Mr. Dryden's hands many years since: The Author of it was unknown to him, and return'd not to claim it; 'Tis therefore to be presum'd that he is dead. After Twelve years expectation, Mr. Dryden gave it to the Players, having upon perusal of it, found that it deserv'd a better Fate than to be buried in obscurity: I have heard him say, that finding a Scene wanting, he supply'd it; and many have affirm • d, that the stile of it is proper to the Subject, which is that the French call Basse Comedy. The turns of it are natural, and the resemblance of one man to another, has not only been the foundation of this, but of many other Plays. Plautus his Amphitrion, was the Original
of all, and Shakespear and Moliere have copied him with success. Nevertheless, if this Play in it self should be a trifle, which you have no reason to suspect, because that incomparable Person would not from his Ingenious labours lose so much time as to write a whole Scene in it, which in it self sufficiently makes you amends, for Poetry being like Painting, where, if a great Master have hut touch'd upon an ordinary Piece, he makes it of Value to all understanding Men; as I doubt not but this will be by his Additions: As it is, I am resolv'd to detain you no longer from it, but subscribe my self,

closer.signed: Your very Humble Servant, R. BENTLEY.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE.
div.l: OVr modest Poet's in as great a fright,
As a young Bride upon her Wedding Night.
She starts and trembles when she sees the Bed.
Like Criminals to execution led:
Alas poor thing she's loath to lose her — Head.
As Boyes stand shivering on a Rivers brim,
Enquire the warmth, and depth, of those that swim.
She cries to Married Friends, what shall I do,
I do so shake, Lord, was it so with you:
And yet she makes a hard shift to go through.
But that once o're what she esteem'd a Crime,
She boldly runs to meet a second Time.
Poets were once as full of trouble too,
But now they're desperate —
To lose this Play as much our Poet strives,
As you to hide your Misses from your Wives.
He thinks your Criticks (and I gad he's right)
Are grown as merciless to those that Write:
As Husbands to their Wives 'oth' Wedding-Night.
You care no more for Poets pains and fears,
Then those vile Men regard poor Womens tears.
You stair and sniff when you're to mischief bent,
As if like Hounds you knew Wit by the scent.
One of our Nymphs should in this Place appear,
But you're so dreadful she's fal'n sick with fear.
Those that pay dear for Love, the veriest Fools,
Though they condemn the work, preserve the Tools.
'Faith for this once let us compound to day,
Be you indulgent to our Orphan Play.
You shall be as much oblig'd another way.

div.head: SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter Learcutt, Mrs. Manley, Isbel and Thom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: GOOD Sir, do not bait me thus.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I'le break thee of this peevish humor, or I'le worry thee;
Thou dost infect my house with melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: This is the height of Tyranny, to chase away
My Comfort, and deny the pleasure of my
Grief too,

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Indeed Couzen, it very ill becomes you, every tear
Drowns part of your Beauty, and every sigh
Carries away in the blast a parcel of your Youth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Alas Couzen! for whom should I preserve it? he that
Owns it, either is not, or else lives a Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I wonder that every thought does not restore thee
To thy self; methinks he having caus'd thy misery,
Thou should'st hate and forget that Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: I rather must hate him that made him one; had you
Been just, we had been happy: I am indebted to your
Avarice for this Discourse, else had we liv'd together in
Peace and plenty.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Yes: while the Eight thousand pounds lasted, when
That had been consumed in Tavern Reckonings, and
Glass Coaches, where then had been the plenty?
I wonder what Allurements of his gain'd thee,
His handsom Structure certainly did not take ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Sir, you know you wrong him; yet granting him not
Handsom, since he lov'd me, and in my behalf
Hath often hazzarded his person, 'twas an
Indearment forc'd me to be grateful.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What? he fought for you! he would have done
As much for his Whore. A Drawer. Iack.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Sir, I can hear no more.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O! he loves you most monsterously, he does
Nothing but think of you: pray how many Reams
Of Letters have you receiv'd from him
Since his departure these Nine years?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Pitty me Heaven, and correct him for it, and if
Iv'e talk'd beyond the duty I owe a Father, pardon it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come, let's after her, ne're let her rest, till
She do quit her folly.

sp.speaker: Isbel,
sp.l: It goes against my Heart, to see her vext thus,
But I must obey. Ex. Mrs▪ Man. Lear. and Isb.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thus do they tire out the poor Gentle woman;
Her Father sent her Husband of an Errand, no man Tables, Chairs and Candles.
Knows whither: well, 'twas an honest Gentleman,
But took not thrifty Courses: I have said often
To him, Mr. Manley; You write a good hand, go
And be a Justices Clerk; there's half a Crown
A Quarter from every House of Sin in the
Precinct, to be shar'd betwixt your Master and your self.
I would have had him set up a Writing-Shcool;
Six pence a Week per Pole, besides command over
The Young Ones; but he would hearken to none of
These things, and now he has been away these
Nine years, and no tydings of him, not so much
As Commendations to me, to his Confident, his Trusty
Thomas, that made up the Match.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Mr. Thomas there is a Gentleman at our house
Desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: With me? what is he prithee?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I don't know indeed, I never saw him before;
But he's a brave Spark; the Gold in his Pocket
Chimes ding dong: and he has bespoke a brave
Supper. Exit Drawer.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Tell him I'le wait upon him; who should this be tro?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Set down your Wine and leave us.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A Quart of Canary in the Rose, Score. Ex. Drawer.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Prithee leave off these palpable Chymera's, these
Witty Nothings; retire yet while you may your
Fame unsully'd.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Prithee forbear thy useless Morals;
Besides, I will not
Stain my Family: a Younger Brother of the house of
Mercury, and baulk at any thing that's not impossible!
But there is probability in this, and profit at the end as
Well as pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: How smooth your Fancy paves a rugged way? and with
What ease you pollish Learcuts harshness? You know
His hate towards him you'd personate, for matching
With the Woman you now aim at; you know his obstinate
Refusal to pay in the Legacy her Grand-Father bequeath'd
Her (Eight thousand pounds I take it,) you know too,
(Which makes your business harder) that this Manley
(Whom you would counterfeit) never enjoy'd her,
Being surpriz'd upon his Wedding-day, and separated
From her by her Father:

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: All this is granted:

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Then how he ruin'd Manley with long Suits, who forc'd
In tender pity to his Wife, whom he foresaw inevitably
Famish'd, lest he submitted to that strict Condition,
Took an Eternal leave of her; and form'd it with a
Sad Vow, never to see her more. Yet notwithstanding
These impediments, you will on.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: And force em, I tell thee here are Pioneers shall do it,
With as much ease as I can fling two Sixes; these
Obstacles you mention fall of course, I will compass the Woman.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis easier to compass the earth: how can you
Have admittance? or if admitted, how, but be discovered;
Though, I confess, Manley and you are alike.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Yes, so like, that it shall ask a subtler head
Then hers to find the difference.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Do not glut thy self with these fantastick hopes,
But sit down fairly here.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Thou knowst I have furnished him with Clothes
And Money; many expensive drunken
Meetings we have had, in order to this grand
Design, and now just ready to possess, shall I desist?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: If there were any colour to think you might
Achieve what you attempt—

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Why, have not I, that I may seem more like
Him, Imprinted here the Scar of such a wound
As he receiv'd in her quarrel once?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: You have.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Then, that he never enjoy'd her, makes for me.
As for the rest in the
Large freedom of our merry Meetings, ther's not
A secret passage in their Love, nor any conceal'd
Agent in the Match: but Iv'e extracted, and have
Sounded his heart,

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: And find it shallow;

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Yet still I'me puzzel'd to think o'th' difficulty of
Access to her.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Seest thou this Boy? this Golden Key Shews a piece of broken Gold.
Opens her Chamber door, although at midnight.

sp.speaker: Vunderw.
sp.l: That piece of Gold!

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: The very same; this piece was broke betwixt
Them at their separation; which is some Nine
Years since: this useful piece, full fraught with
Wine, I did perswade him out of, at our last Jovial
Bout at Rotterdam:

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: What, when you promis'd to be his Solicitor, and
Re-instate him in his Wife and Fortunes?

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: That very time.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: You swore you would perform it.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: I'le forget that; for men whose Lands and Wealth
Lie in this Circle Pointing to his Head.
Must not stick at trifles: are you resolv'd, or will
You prove a Recrant?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: I'le on, whether I fall or swing with thee.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Come Infidel, obey but the directions I give thee,
And be a punctual Servingman:

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Do not doubt me, — but stay a little, it has been
Often in my thoughts to ask, and still some other
Business has diverted me: what should be the reason
That you refus'd to accept money for the Ship you
Won last night at Gravesend?

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Not impertinently, I warrant thee thou shalt know
Further suddenly: do not you fail your part, If I
Miscarry, hang me up for a Pryapus to scare
High flying Wits.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: And if I wait not with a Trencher to an Inch, discard
Me your service, without a Ticket of my Truth.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: I hear some body coming up stairs; observe your distance.
Honest Thomas, how dost thou? how hast thou done this
Long time honest Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: 'Troth Sir, as you see, I want Clothes, and money, and the
Best can do no more Sir.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Well, thou art strangely altered since we parted,
I protest I scarce know thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And truly Sir, I cannot know you by instinct: It may
Be you know me, but truly Sir I never saw you before.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Thomas, I did not think you would so easily forget
Your Friends; not know me Thomas! 'tis strange! your
Memory is very weak.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By my troth, to my knowledge, I never saw you
Before Sir.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: No, come here's to thee Thomas. Drinks.
Look on me well, and recollect thy self:

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let me see, truly Sir, now I look upon you well,
You are very like—no body that ever I saw in all
My life.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Well, well, persist in that opinion.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Take off your Wine, before two Glasses more, you'l
Change your Dialect.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Truly Sir, I was never worthy of such worshipful
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Thomas, complement with your old Friends!
Your Wine pawles:

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sir, I pledge you, and make bold to drink to your
Friend here: —Pray Sir excuse me, I'le fill it;
Will you please to pledge me?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Pray Sir excuse me, I do not use to drink
Among my Masters Companions.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: His Master! this is some Great Man, some Knight I
Warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: But speak seriously Thomas, dost thou know
Me, or dost thou dissemble with me?
Methinks our Friendship should be of too long growth
To be forgotten: One Glass of Wine to me, and try if
Yet you can remember: Sit down, view every
Character in my Face; did you ever behold
Any thing like it?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Truly, I have seen a Face resemble yours.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: O! do you remember now! where pray?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Among the brazen Tombs at Westminster.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: There he has hit you. Aside.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: It seems you reckon me among the Dead then.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: That's dexterously warded.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: I thought that had I been deceased, I should have liv'd
Still in your thoughts; but since you have banish'd
Me your memory—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why? would you have me remember a Gentleman
I never set eyes on before?

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: No Thomas; why, whom did you bring down to me to
My Father in Law's back door? whom did you
Put into the Coach to me, and wait upon to Pancridge?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pray let me review you; that is his Nose, and those
His Eyes, or I'me mistaken.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: I, I'le swear thou art. Aside.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: 'Tis Mr. Manley; what a Beetle was I? forgive me
Good Sir, sweet Sir pardon me; for as I'me an honest
Man y'are the strangest altred! Lord! I should
Never have known you, but by that Token.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: This is a pure Coxcomb. Aside.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Your voice is altred too.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: See what 'tis to Travel Thomas!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And how, and how, and how dee Sir? by my troth
I'me glad to see you Sir.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Kind Thomas thank thee, how fares it with my
Poor Wife? has she been pleasant since?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Poor Soul! I think in my conscience, had not
You come to night, she had dyed to morrow;
She has took on most lamentably, not look'd
Kindly on her Victuals since you parted; and for Drink,
She dyets her self with a small quantity, to keep
Her in Tears; that she may not want utterance
For her sorrow: I am perswaded the Current of
Her Eyes would go nigh to drive a Mill.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: I come purposely to stop up the Stream, or divert
It in to pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You will be a welcome man to her: good Gentlewoman!
I came but just now from her, there was the
Heaviest quarter! truly, they e'ne weary her out
Of her life: if she had not had the more Grace,
She had en'e gone to Heaven before this time.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Dear Soul! the hour is come to consummate
Thy sorrows!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Her Father was just now
Upbraiding you for a poor fellow, worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Nor am I, till I have her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: 'Tis no Pilgrimage to her Sir: yet methinks the
World's pretty well mended since our last interview.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Faith I have waited long for it; it was some
Years before I and all the Friends I could make,
Could perswade my Uncle to exchange this
Transitory life for a better.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What Uncle Sir, I beseech you? you never told me
Of this Uncle until now.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Faith Tom, I did never think he would have dyed,
And that was the reason.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I hope he has left you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Pretty well, as thou seest Thomas; come sit down:
Faith we'll be brave Boyes, he has left me all.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Truly I am very glad of it, how much pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: A poor trifle, some Hundred thousand pounds,
Besides six Ships that have been out a seven years
Voyage to the Indies, which I every hour expect here:
I left em at the Rivers mouth: here's to their save arrival.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Sir, there are a couple of men below enquire for you.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Go down Sirrah, and see who they are.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Sir, I believe the fellows come for the six
Flanders Mares, will you please to pay 'em your self,
Or shall I?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: I pay 'em, you superfluous Coxcomb! what did I give you money for?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: I flie Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: To see how these Rogues will trouble a man for every
Trifle: fill me a glass of Wine; here fill my Friend one:
Here's to you Sweet-heart, Thomas. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By my troth I'le pledge it Sir, without Sugar.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Sir, there's the Coach-maker without too, he will not
Take under a Hundred and fifty pounds: Sir I am unwilling—

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: You Rogue, must I be troubled with every idle Two
Or three hundred pounds? pay him and be hang'd,
Or I'le pay you, and send you to your Friends again
To eat Sprats.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: I vanish and obey you with dexterity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Come Thomas, here's t'other Brimmer to thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, but by my troth I dare not stay,
My Master will be mad with me.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Prithee man, a little longer.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Upon my word I dare not.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Then Thomas, present this to my Wife: Gives him a broken piece of Gold.
And my Heart with it; that Heart that
Broke with this, and never was whole since Fate
Divided us.

sp.speaker: Tho,
sp.l: I warrant you you shall be with her presently:
I'le but whisper a word in my Old Masters Ear.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: No, no, I do not like that, if my arrival's know
We shall be troubled with the unwelcome kindness
Of our civil Friends, and hindred of that privacie
That Lovers thirst after: conceal me then from all,
Unless her self. Tell her when all are quiet
I'le wait on her: when her Father and the Houshold
Are asleep I'le visit her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Well Sir, I'le make bold to tell her so.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: When thou deliver'st to her this Emblem
Of our Separation, tell her we now shall
Meet never to part.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'le be very punctual. How my Young Mistress
Will leap out of her skin, to hear the News I bring her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: Now Vnderwit let's laugh at this fellow
For an hour.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: And sit down, or I shall be weary of it.
Well, th'art a gallant Fellow, thou deserv'st to
Stand a Stair higher then ordinary in the Pillory.

div.head: The SCENE, Learcut's House.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: There she stands, they have driven her from her.
Supper, and now she steals to her Closet, that there
She may banquet on her sighs: a very unwholsome
Dyet, and denotes a windy Stomach.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: How am I condem'd without hope of reprieve, not to
Dye once, but to be ever gasping.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Iv'e a Receipt at my tongues end to cure your melancholy:
O Mistress!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: What ails thee? more torments yet: yet, shall I be never quiet?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Will you never leave this peevish humour of weeping?
Can you tell what you cry for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Fool: dost thou enquire the Cause, that wert the Instrument, to give me up to him whose loss I mourn?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: 'Troth you have no great cause to weep for the matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Art thou revolted too? ungrateful—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay, no bad words good Mistress, you know I was your friend
To bring you together: (an exploit, if known, would
Set me at liberty) and if I find no friendlier language,
I'le never bring you together again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: I easily believe thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: But what would you say, if I tell you where he is?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: On that condition I would be a Bond-slave.
But why flatter I my self?
Or why believe delusions?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, no, do not; for if you can give credit to my Senses,
Till you believe your own, you'l find, and speedily,
He's no distressed Indigent, forlorn Fellow; but a
Gallant and a brave one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Do not abuse me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Be not you incredulous, for he is near and wealthy,
Can shovel Gold for a wager with your Father, and —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: How willingly I would believe thee, and how little
Can I.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Can you believe this? Gives her the Gold.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Sure my senses do not conspire against me:
Dear Friend, tell me quickly, where may I find the Owner.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, no, I'me a Tormentor!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Prithee do not wrack me, but tell me where
I may meet my Manley.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, in your Bed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Do not delude me, he is not there.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, but he will be, he sent me to give
You intelligence; he'l be with you when the
Old man's laid asleep, and the house hush: he
Desires you to put out the Candles, that he
May be the less noted: he would have his
Arrival conceall'd from all but you: he's on
Fire to pay you some arrears which were owing
You on your Wedding night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Art thou alive still! then Heaven has not let
Me pray and weep in vain.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: When you see him, you'l swear it, he is not the
Quondam man, in the thread-bare-breeches and no money,
But dazelling Scarlet, lac'd and lin'd with Gold:
His Coach richly drawn by six Milk-white Mares,
Guarded with Pages and Laqueys drest like Hinch-boyes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Can this wonder be?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Else never trust your trusty Thomas: go
Mistress, will you about your business,
Hasten the House to rest, for you'l get little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: By his presence, more then I have had this nine years.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Beshrew his heart then, I do but think how you'l smile to morrow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: And I hope ever.
Return my Husband my obedience. She goes out.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What life this has put into her! the very apprehension of this same harlotry matter makes her as nimble as an Eele riggling in the mud. Well, I have brought you twice together now, if you part again, I shall have an ill conceit of my labour.

div.stage: Learcuts House. Mrs. Manley and Isbel with a Light as to Bed.

sp.speaker: Isbel.
sp.l: Forsooth, Couzen, will you make haste to Bed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Excuse me, I'm indispos'd.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: And ever are so; my Uncle has told over the Bags in the
Chest by this time, and when he hath said his prayers with
Beads, you know he wakes not long; if he hears us stir
After him, he'l lay suspicion of Felony to our charges;
Swear we conspire with his Servants to drink out the March
Beer: Good Forsooth to bed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Troth Cousin, I believe I shall not sleep to night,
And know, then I'm an unruly Bed-fellow:
I do nothing but tumble and toss.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Truly, and that's fine sport sometimes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Sweet Cousin, let me intreat yt our absence, the Maid
Has laid you a pair of clean Sheets in the Red Chamber.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Indeed Cousin, you are not to be trusted alone, for fear
You weep to death.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Trust me, I will not weep at all.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Well then, if it must be so, I'le humour you, though I
Doubt, to your prejudice, on the condition you'l neither be
Drownd in your Tears to morrow, nor parch't up to Mummy in
Your long winded sighs of an Ell, London measure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Good rest to you dear Cousin, have you laid on the
Finest sheets, as I bid you?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Yes, indeed Forsooth, and made the Bed high, towards the
Feet, as you bid me likewise.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Is my Cambrick-Holland-Night-tyre in the Sweet-Bag?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: As you would please to have it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Then make haste to Thomas, and
Tell him I'm a Bed. Mrs. Manley goes out.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Make haste to Thomas and tell him I'm in Bed: Those were the words. Is all this ado for Thomas? Were you so hasty you could not unlace your self, but you must cut? Did you for this tear off your Handkerchief, because I could not unpin it fast enough? Must Thomas handsel your new Linnen? Will a fit of Mirth with him cure you of a Nine years Melancholy? Well, well, little would any one think it were in her; but I'le watch your water: for Thomas, I Faith, I know he'l be constant to his poor Bell, that gave him two yards of Ferret Ribbond t'other day for a pair of Shoe-strings. As I am very Woman, look where he is! he talks to himself too: I'le hide my self, and find it out.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
The Old One's laid; now if the Young One were, my work were ended: but what do I deserve for my contrivance? what reward must I expect for all the Wit I have expended in
this business? I shall, at least, be Steward when they keep house; then will I take Poundage for all the Bills I pay, besides my New-Years-Gifts: or say, he give me one of his Ships; I, I, I, that's most likely; for he'l never trouble himself with such Lumber: then will I Trade into the Straits, and in three years be an Alderman — But Thomas, Thomas, what if a Turks Man of War take her, what wilt thou do then? No, there's Mortality in one Ship— he will give me two, and with those two I'le defie Mahomet of Algiers—But suppose he gives me all the Ships — Yes, yes, I'm sure he will give me all the Ships; how shall I bestow 'em then? Let me see, let me see— Yes it shall be so— I will way-lay the Spanish Carrukes coming from the Indies, and master em. But whom should I intrust with the Command of this Fleet? for I dare not look Salt Water in the Face my self, since an Innes of Court Man stal'd on me out of a Tavern Window once: if I should trust it to one and he should cheat me, and keep all to himself, what a pickle were I in then? No, no, I must find out some other expedient.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: I'le do my errand to him, if it be but to feel his pulse.
My Mistress —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Having three or four Knights to wait on me in blew Coats
After the old fashion —

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: What, will you not hear me Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To whom I will allow thirty pounds wages, besides their Vales — And my Footmen ten shillings a week Board-wages.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Passion of me, I begin to fear; he did not use to deal thus Scornfully with me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And two new Suits a year—

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: This vexes me, but I'le set a face on't as if I car'd not for him.
Well sullen Fool, I must tell you my message, and therefore
Take notice of it — Pulls him by the sleeve.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O! Right Trusty and Well-belov'd Isbel, I cry thee mercy,
I did not see thee.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: No, not you: some body will repent this.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By the Faith of my Body, my dainty Duck—

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Well said dissembler: no, no, you are for my Mistress Palate:
She commanded me just now, to make haste to you, and tell
You she was in Bed. I have not been a Chamber Maid so▪
Long, but I can construe her part of Speech without an Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Farewell till by and by. Goes out.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: So soon vanished?

What's the reason, tro? he's gone down stairs, though that's not the way to her: Well Thomas, well, the case is altered, and may be again shortly: then good Isbel mend my Stockins, and sweet Isbel look my Head, and we'l go to Islington, and drink Ale in an Arbour: is there no Faith in Sugar-Cakes and Cream? Are Custards and Cheese-cakes hollow-hearted? Well, I faith I'le be coyer then I have been for this trick. Go thy ways, thou should'st never have kiss'd me as thou hast done, if I thought thou wouldst have served me so: but what's done is done, and cannot be helped.
Here he comes again, ha! what Gallant is that with him?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir, this way. Hazzard gives his Spurs
Tread softly, for fear my Master hear you.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.p: Why, he's almost asleep at best, for he's somewhat deaf: Both his Eyes and Ears are lock • d fast enough now I believe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I, but you must think a man who has waded in oppression these Fifty or Threescore years has some Monitors, that give his conscience an Item, when he offers to wink.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: I'le let em pass, but I'le observe em narrowly.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: You are sure she has no manner of light in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: But her light Heart I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Have we any more Rooms to go through before We come at hers?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: She lies in the very same Chamber she did when you Woo'd her: the blew Room on the right hand Sir.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Faith 'tis so long ago, I've almost forgotten it. Id Almost spoyl'd all: good night Thomas, I'le grope out the Bed My selfe. Exit with Thomas.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Is this the trick on't? then I see I wrong'd my
Faithful Thomas—but yet he wrongs me, and takes
My Office from me, and so I'le tell him: Enter Thomas.
How now Thomas, from whence came you thus laden?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
My pretty Bell I'le tell thee; thy Mistresses Husband having
been outed his Free Tenement, is newly gone to make his entry on it.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Is that Mr. Manley?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: The very Hee.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Truly he's a handsom Gentleman: 'tis a thousand pities—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What, a thousand pities that he's a handsom Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: No, but that he should not live with her: I warrant he's A good Comforter.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I, my aimable Belly, so would I be to thee, if thou would'st
But be plyable!
But we men may speak our hearts out, you remorseless
Virgins will either not hear us, or not believe us. How
Often have I robb'd my Masters Bolsters of the Keys o'th'
Celler? and w • had swil'd the Wine out, broke the Bottles,
And told him 'twas the strength o'th' Wine?
Yet thou hadst no more —

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Well Thomas, well, you have no great reason to say so,
Have not I found thee Handkerchiefs these two years?
Have I not starch't thy Bands to bid defiance to thy Masters?
Have I not sewed on thy little peeping Cuffs? Nay, have I
Not slighted a Lords Footman for thee?
Hast not thou compar'd my Leggs, and untied my Garters?
Even yet canst thou call me hard?
Unthankful Thomas! Unhappy Isbel! She Cries.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Then, Heart split asunder for very joy! Dear Chicken!
I will dry thy Tears up with my Lips! Honey forgive me!

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O! did I ever think this? He kisses her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No more tryals of thy Love, my Dear!

div.stage: He embraces her, and in the Extasy drops the Boots and Spurrs.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.l: Thieves, thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Passion o' me! the Old Man's awake.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.l: Thomas, Andrew, Thieves here!

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: What shall we do? he'l catch us, and then w'are undone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Do you go that ways to bed? Isbel goes out.
Ile make down this way.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Are my Knaves all deaf? shall I be murdered here? why
Thomas, Andrew—
sp.stage: To him Learcut coming up stairs he justles Thomas and falls on his knees, frighted.
sp.l: O! here they are: Good Gentlemen, as y'are Gentlemen
Do not hurt an old man!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Do you take me for a Thief, Sir? 'tis I, Sir; Thomas.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thomas? Let me look better on thee, is not that
A Dark Lanthorn in thy hand?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No Sir, 'tis a Pewter Candlestick.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I think it be indeed: well Sirrah you put me into
A villanous cold Sweat: but sure I heard a noise.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Alas, Sir! it was nothing but a humming in your head.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I, and I heard a chink too like money.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Trust your own Eyes, if I have lost my credit with you,
Look round about the House.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I like the motion well, go before me, Thomas.
sp.stage: They go out and return again.
sp.l: The Windows and Bolts are all secure: doth no body lie under
The Tables or the Stools. He stumbles on the Boots.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Now all will out, I must reveal my secret.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ha! Thomas, how came these here?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Since it can no longer be hidden from you, be pleased to
Know, there's a Gentleman within in Bed with my young Mistress,
Who will not be afraid to own 'em.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What? are you turn'd Pander? set up in my own house?
Begin with my Daughter? come out thou Villain, Ile have
Thee Carted.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Good words, good words, and not too loud for fear of disturbing the young Couple; if this noise should make the Gentleman miscarry, 'twould be no small grief to your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How have I been deluded in thee! out Impudence,
Avow thy roguery!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, Sir, not taking notice at present of an Action of Slander, but desiring you to keep those termes to your self, to be as short as you have been with me, Your travelling Son-in-Law, having followed the track of Sir Francis Drake's Ship, is returned hither again; and now Vlysses is with his Penelope.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Villain: I had rather she had been a Whore. Andrew, rise,
Fetch the Constable; I'le have him to the Gaol,
He comes to rob me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Softly, softly good Master! for if he over-hear you, y'are
Undone; he'l recover God knows what of you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Hang him, beggerly▪ Rascal! I'le have him whipt, he
Has a Plot upon me; he lies with my Daughter to fill my
House with Vermin to destroy my goods.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, Sir, do you think he'l beget Rats and Weazels?
I'm of a clear contrary opinion; for I have a conceit he
Will get Children in embroydered Coats. Alas, alas, Sir! he's
None of the Old Master Manley, who courted me for the Wing
Of a mangled Capon; would kiss the Leg on't as 't had been his
Mistresses Hand, and stand gazing on the Carcase, admiring
The fair proportion of the Body.
He's now in his glass Coach lin'd through with Velvet,
Attended by his Pages and Laqueys, that look
Like running Rain-bows: prances in State to Fish-street,
Eats of his twenty Dishes at a Dinner, maintains a brace
Or two of Wits at's Table, and —

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Is't impossible!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: It is most certain.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Why what Estate hath he?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A small trifle of some Hundred thousands of pounds in
Money, besides a dozen Ships that have been trading for
Pearl in the Indies, and ride now at Gravesend.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thou do'st amaze me! how i'th' name of Goodness
Did he compass it?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: It was an Uncle, when he died left him all this.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Do'st thou think there's no cheat in't?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, Sir, he sent to me to prove his Unkles Will at the
Office, I took out Letters of Administration for him.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And art thou certain he hath so many rich Ships?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Certain? Lord, Sir, you make such a question of it, why
I receiv'd but to day, Letters from the Masters of 'em all,
And all their Bills of Lading.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How long hath he been in Town?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not above a fortnight, Sir

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: So long? and neither I, nor my Daughter know it?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: For you, he took some old passages to heart, to tell you
The truth, I think he was dogged.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Alas! good Gentleman! why should he be angry with me?
I never hurt him, only my Daughter being a tender gristle, I was
Loath he should overstrain her: but I'le make him amends for't.
But hear you Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes Sir —

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.l: Bring my Sable Jerkin down with you, and call Isbel by
Th' way, we'l congratulate the conjunction of those small Plants.
Thomas to bed; disturb not the Young Couple:
There let 'em lie for me, and take their ease,
Since Manley's Rich, he may do what he please.

div.stage: Enter Thomas, and Isbel in her Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh Isbel! fie, fie; Isbel, fie.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O the Lord! Thomas, where, where is the Fire? I'le
Be hang'd if it be not in our Neighbours house
The Pewterer; for they are up knocking
Early and late: out upon't how it stinks, my Mistress,
My Mistress will be burnt in her bed.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Gad, that's unhappily said, for I'm sure there's hot
Work by this time, Isbel offers to go.
Stay inhumane Isbel, still insensible, here is the
Fire; thou like a careless Maid, hast thrown
The burning Snuf of thy Beauty into the
Chink of my Heart, there it has smother'd long:
But now, like Aetna, it breaks out, and throws
Hot Stones and melted Mettle up▪

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Poh! now I hate you Mr. Thomas, so I do; you
Wak'd me out of the sweetest Dream! high ho.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pritty unconscionable Rogue! tell me thy Dream,
And I'll let thee go.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Then I'le tell't yee, to be rid of yee, methought
Mr. Thomas, I had a grievous fit of the Mother;
And they burnt Feathers and soles of old Shoes under
My Nose, but still it rose and rose like to
Choak me; till a brisk young Doctor came, and turn'd
All out of the Room, and then — Ah! you'l laugh
At me: I won't—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What? the Doctor threw thee on the Bed—

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Then got upon thee, and held thee down with
All his strength.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Then tickled thee soundly, till thou turn'st up
Like a Trout in the water.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O dear! Doctor! I was never so sweetly cur'd
In all my life, and he would not take a farthing
Of me. I was just falling into another Fit when
You woo'd me, with a mischief to you; I have forgot
The Doctors name too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Poor Mistress Isbel! fear not, I'le cure thee when
Thou wilt; I will so tickle thee!

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Ah! tickle me thereabout! any body can
Tickle me thereabout. Oh the sweet Heavens!
We shall be hang'd if our Mistress hear us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Our Mistress hear us! if ten couple of Cats were
Making Love at her Pillow, and all the Kings Lyons
Roaring at her Beds feet, she would not hear.
Her Husband, our Master is a Bed with her: I call'd thee
Up to tell thee of it.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: What? Our Master that has been a married Batchelor
These nine years?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The same: and they are just now dancing
The beginning of the World.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O the sweet Father! I warrant our Mistress will tell
Him such Tales, and ask him forty questions.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I, and have such grievous Fits of the Mother, Isbel!

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: For the Lords sake, what kind of man is he?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A very handsome, neat, accomplish'd, gentile,
Pretty man, much of my make, and something
Like me; and I'le assure you, well bred; for he
Swore Damme, and call'd me Son of a Whore

Twenty times, and then he gave me a
• uinney:
But as soon as I was out of the Room, the Bed
Crack'd like a Ship breaking on the Sands,
And my Mistress cry'd out like a drowning
Passenger, Ah! —

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Alas! poor Mistress! if he should overlay her
Mr. Thomas!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay, I'me sure he had some ill design,
For his Eyes roll'd, and his Colour did come
And go, and he shook all over, as if he
Had the Palsie.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Mr. Thomas, you are a Fool.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Fool! Nay, if you go to that, I hearken'd
At the door, and I'le take my Oath I heard her
Cry, O deer! O Sweet Husband! Ah!
And then I could hear no more.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Now am I so afraid to go to bed;
For I shall dream of nothing but
Dying; and falling into such grievous Fits,
That the very bed will tremble: O sweet Doctor!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I tell thee, I'm as good a Doctor at that
As any breathing: But talk not of bed
Before we have drank to their Hans in Kelder.
Come, let's to the Pantery.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let them with too much Love destroy each other:
Good Wine is better then the Fits o'th' Mother.

div.head: SCEN. I. A Bed-Chamber, Mrs. Manley running in, in Night-Cloaths, Hazzard after her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: ALas! I am betray'd! 'tis not my Husband.

sp.speaker: Hazz.
sp.l: How now, my Heart! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Now I'm confirm'd; that's not his voice.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: What would'st thou have? can'st thou not speak for it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: One unhappy! O thou slie dissembler!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Dissembler? 'tis a word I understand not:
By thy own Fair Self, not one unmeant Oath
Of my affection hath escap'd my Lips.
Fair Sweetness! what a Paradice of Beauty!
'Twas well I saw thee not e're I enjoy'd thee. Aside.
She is so lovely! I could ev'n repent
I have deceiv'd her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Was my Chastity
So envi'd by thee, thou must rob me of it?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: By this Light, Madam,
You are the first Wife ever complained of that fault.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: With what Forehead
Darest thou call me so?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Is Pancrass fallen down? or the Church burnt there?
The Parson, or our Parent-Clark deceas'd?
Or are you cloy'd, and surfeited on a Husband
After so long a Fast, that you dare ask
That Question?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Impudent Ravisher! unhand me;
Thou art not he; but some false Villain
Disclos'd these secrets to thee, and betray'd me.
Let me go Monster; I will fly from thee. She struggles to get from him
Into some Desart, where the direful Screech-Owls—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Prithee cast off this whining foolish humor: Kisses her. & whispers her aside.
Be plyable; come, come,
You'l n'ere be right till I —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: This startles me: this private token speaks him.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: That stagger'd her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: I know not what to think on't.
Those Eyes, that Hair is very — He:
But, O! that Voice, like the Devils cloven Foot
Discovers an Impostor. Hence; I loath thee.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Art thou incurable for ever?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Yes: unless thou could'st restore me my stol'n Honor.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: For that Fair Sweetness sake that once dwelt in thee
I am content to please thee to my ruine.
I'le take one Journey more, whose period
Shall be my Tomb; I'le travel to my death:
For 'tis no matter now whither I wander, Weeps
Since I have lost that dwelling which I had
In thy once tender and relenting Breast.
Yet for the Love you once pretended to me,
Deny not the last Kiss to a dying Martyr. Kisses her.
Farewel for ever:
The Darts of Scorn are sharper far then those
Of Anger. He unbuttons and shews his Breast.
This wound thou hast given me, strikes deeper here
Then e're Rivals Sword did.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Bless me! I'm amazed! Haz. offers to go out.
It should be he! and yet methinks it cannot:
Pray good Sir, stay, Alas! my troubled Brain's
Distracted 'twixt the Love and Doubt of you;
And by two Strengths of equal pow'r my Fears
And my Affections bend two several wayes:
Trembling I stand! tortur'd between them both;
But cannot yeild to the force of either.
So willingly I pray to be deceived,
That I could wish one Sense a Traytor to me,
For all things else conspire in your reception;
But this old trusty servant, the Sense of Hearing
Evinces plainly you are not the man.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: That Servant you call Trusty, is a Traytor,
Or an o're-diligent officious Servant,
Whose care creates imaginary difficulties
And dangers, where the way is safe, and easie.
Please to consult the Steward of your Soul,
And Ruler of your Senses, Your wise Reason.
Ask if nine Winters Cold, nine Summers Heats,
And almost a continual emptiness
Can chuse but alter th' Organs of the Voice?
Oh! Madam, Madam, did you know my Story,
You'd rather wonder I can speak at all,
Then that my Tone is chang'd: if that be all
The scruple, from this hour I will be dumb;
And give no food to your distrust.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: It must be he.
Sir, you may spare that Pennance; I'le delight
To hear you tell with this Voice, how your old one
Departed from you, and by frequent hearing
Forget the difference of their sounds. Believe me!
My heart shall ever be so full of joyes
For your deliverance; I will not weep
When you relate your Sorrows.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Love, I am now thy Sacrifice, on this
Thy living Alter I lay down my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: May the same fire that burns the Victim, seize
The Altar too, since I am it.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: How charming she looks now?
When she was conceiv'd, her Mother look't on Lillies.
O! I could stare for ever here! Wild Poetry!
Creatrix of Impossibilities,
Shew me but such another 'mong thy Quire
Of Goddesses, and I'le forgo my Conquest.

div.stage: Thomas and Isbel with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Make haste, my Young Master may chance to long for
Some excuse to be call'd away from his labour.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Mistress, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir here's an Attendant of yours, a wise Maid that knows the smack of her Mistresses Pallate, and gives a shrewd guess at the sharpness of yours, has brought you a Repairer of Falling Nature, and your Father-in-law is in the next Room, who Desires to be inform'd, whether your Wife have breath enough left to ask him blessing.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Prithee, bid the Wench come in, and tell my Father
We'll wait upon him presently.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Will you please to come in Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Good morrow, Good morrow Children,
God bless you both.
What? ha' you gotten me a Grand-Child to night?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: If we ha' not, Sir, 'tis the fault of the Planets, and not of us,
For I have plow'd and sow'd in a rich mould.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O, Forsooth Cousin, was it for this you shifted me off
Last night? is your Melancholy melted away
In a Feather-bed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Prithee Couz. excuse me, I'le give thee leave
To cheat me so.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Beshrew me, Forsooth; but your Husband's
A Gallant Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Sweet Heart, here's my Cosin Isbel.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: So, So, I'm glad I know my Cousins name. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: She is a Lady, whom without a Letter of Attorney,
From you, I made your Substitute in my Bed.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, sweet Cousin Isb salutes him.
I'm much oblig'd to you for the Pains you have taken on my
Wife in my absence. I hope, my good Cousin,
Your Father and Mother are well.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You are mistaken, Son, this is my Cousin Edwards daughter.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: O! I cry you mercy sweet Cousin, I thought
You had been my other Cousins Daughter.
'Twas well I had two Cousins. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Isbel come after me, and dress me.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What a fine proper Gentleman my Son is grown?
Of what a goodly Garb and Presence! truly, Son, I sent two or
Three several Messengers to hearken after you.

sp.speaker: Tho,
sp.l: Yes: whether he were dead or no.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: O, thank you heartily, loving kind Father for your care,
But I never saw any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The worse luck mine; I hope you tak't not ill.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: No indeed Father.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Son, here's a Toy, pray desire your wife Gives a Carcanet
To take it in good part; she shall have more speedily
When I die.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You are too bountiful, Sir, by this Light Oriental.
sp.stage: Opens it and gives it to Thomas.
sp.l: Tom, Go carry this to my Wife, it is her Fathers
Blessing, tell her.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And Thomas, fetch up the great Plate, and
Set it on the Cupboard in the Chamber—
And the Looking-Glass inlay'd with Pearl that
The Knight pawn'd, and forfeited. Thomas goes out.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: The Old man will grow mad sure.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Nay, Son, now you take good Courses, my assistance
Shall not be wanting to you. Cryes.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: A pretty Gentleman! why was not I a dozen years elder?
'Tis a wish few women e're were known to sigh after, and yet
I grieve I am not; then it might have been my fortune to have
Taken the Love my Cousin now enjoyes. I cannot now think
Thy tears were in vain. Now I'm amaz'd thou didst not
Die for him. Then had not I dispaired for him,
Or been content with transitory Thomas.
I'le to my Cousin and forget him. She goes out.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Come Father what service will you command me?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: We'll e'n down to dinner and drink healths
To Hans in Kelder.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Have you burnt any Juniper in the Parlour?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, Sir. Thomas holds up the Hangings.
Come in Iack, come in.

div.stage: Enter Underwit with a Cabinet and a Packet.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: How now Iack? what hast thou brought? my Cabinet?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Yes, Sir: and here's a Packet from Van Stoven.
Your Factor in the Mary. Hazzard reads the Letter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Some good News sure; for he is very well pleas'd at it.
It tickles him, he smiles.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: How long is't since these came?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Some two hours since, Sir.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Well then, I have leisure to stay here till Evening,
But then Father, I must crave your dispensation, and my Wives
Leave for this Night, the reason you may read there, if you
Vouchsafe the favour.

body.p:
Hououred Sir, my Love to you remembred; I received Yours of the Fourteenth Instant, wherein you commanded me to send you the state of your Affairs. I came down this Tyde with the Mary, and in my
company came the Unicorn to Gravesend; the Leopard, the Tygar, the Crane, and the John of London we expect the next Tyde. The Marriners are greedy for Money, because they have not any to fee the Searchers to let their Parcels go uncustom'd; wherefore your presence, some time this Evening would be necessary: you need not bring above twelve hundred pounds Sterling with you, for I have here near three thousand Pieces of Eight in Cash aboard. I have sent you herewith the Bills of Lading of your Six Ships for fear the former I sent you by Peter Horen might miscarry. I have nothing else at present to write, but that it would please Heaven to bless you; and so I rest,

closer.signed: Your Trusty and Faithful Servant. [Here's a name will make my mouth ake.] Hercules Herman Vansloven.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Now, he's poring on the Bills of Lading, where there are Parcels enough to furnish the City these twenty years.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Coperas, Coperas, Coperas—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Yes: with Gall of your Worshipful Conscience,
Will make fine Ink for the Devil to write withall.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Indico, Indico—Scutchionele, Ingots of Gold—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: As much as you can lift; this old Coxcomb will stand
Poring there till his Spectacles grow blind:
I must put him out of it: Iack, come hither, have you
Receiv'd those Bills of Exchange from Hans?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: He has accepted them, Sir, and for your present
Occasion sent you a Thousand pounds, but will not pay
The rest till the Bills are due, whereof Eight days
Are unexpired; so there remains upon 'em
Seven thousand pounds and upwards.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: More wealth yet? sure he hath got a Colledge of coining
Devils at his beck: else this was impossible.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Give me the Bills. Come, Sir, will you walk down
Into the Garden?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I, Son, there we'll confer.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: My Heart, prithee make haste down, I am no body
Without thee. Between the Scenes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: I obey you instantly.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What a fortunate man am I in a Loving and a Rich Son?
In the afternoon we'll to Gleek till towards evening.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: By that time my Coach may come, if you intend to make
Visits to day.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sir, just as I was going down through the Hall, I met
The noise of Fidlers that use to play the Healths to you, who heard
Of your arrival, will not be kept out with twenty Whifflers.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Bid 'em strike up hastily; but thrust out that
Old Violin that uses to set mens Teeth on edge.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Shall old blind David with the Harp come in Sir, he playes
Sellingers Round in Sippets the rarest—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: If he do, remove the Cloaks into the Buttery,
He can feel, though he cannot see.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l:
I will Sir.
They go all out but Thomas.
Do you hear Porter, put out the Mandrake with the
Squeaking Christopher: Set the blind Harper in the Corner.
Now Fidlers, scrape your Guts till your Hearts ake.

div.stage: A Dance and Song concludes the Act. Mrs. Manley, Isbel, and another Maid in the Dance.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: 'Tis very well: Now Son let's in to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: We wait upon you, Sir: Come my Dear Love,
Though Fortune and your Father once have try'd us,
Their utmost spight again shall n'ere divide us:
In kind Embraces we our lives will waste,
And double Joyes to come, for Sorrows past.

div.head: SCEN. I. A Chamber with a Bed in it.
div.stage: Enter Hazzard, and Underwit with a Pillow under his Cloak. On a Cupboard Plate and Iewels.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: SWeet Love, make as much haste home again
As you can.
I shall be sick till I see you again. I'm afraid almost to trust
You out of my sight, your former Voyage runs so in my mind.

div.stage: Underwit packs the Plate and Iewels into the Pillowbear.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: I will be back again to night, if possible.
Business must be look'd after Sweet-heart: Once more
Farewell till to morrow.
Here, Sirrah, take this Gold with you. Gives him a Purse.
Hast thou got all? Aside.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Not left a Silver Spoon, nor a Hook to hang
A Napkin at.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Away then, make haste, and get aboard the Ship I won at
Gravesend: she rides now by Cuckolds Haven:
Stay there till I come to thee.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Why, will you not along with me? methinks
It would be very convenient to fly away in that
For fear of a surprise. We have got a handsom
Pittance that will make us live like Princes.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: 'Tis not meer Avarice incites me further; but a Design
Of higher consequence.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: What then, wouldst have the Wench away too?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Prithee be not scrutinous, but obedient; give out
That you are bound for the Barbados, and let your
Streamers be display'd, that I may know you.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: But heark you, I must share in the Woman too,
When we come to America.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: No more words, but away, lest some of the Servants
Should discover you; Sirrah Iack, make haste after me,

I'le stay at Limehouse for you.
He goes out talking aloud with Underwit.

div.head: The SCENE, Learcut's House.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Will you please to have a Fire this Evening, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Unthrifty Knave! hast thou a Plot upon my Charcoale,
Thou seek'st their ruine thus?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Truly, Sir, this Weather would endure two in latter fire;
And your Worship knows that is your stint.
(If I do not think Aside.
His body's as miserable as his Conscience, I'm no upright
Foreman.) The Thames is frozen over above-Bridge, Sir, and
Sackcloth-Towns are built upon't: 'tis such a Season, Sir,
Zeal cannot warm a man: for a Fanaticks Teeth, as he
Pass'd by just now, shattered, as if one had plaid a Tune
On the Gridiron.

div.stage: To them Isbel running in haste, and presently after Mrs. Manley.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How now? whither so fast? Is your Mistress
In labour already?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O Lord, forsooth, Sir, my Mistress is undone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The more shame for her Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: O Father, we are robb'd.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: That very Word sticks like a cake of Ice at my heart.
I dare not ask of what.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: All your Plate, and the Jewels you gave me
Are vanished, as if they had been Apparisions.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, this comes of keeping no Fire in the house,
Any manner of light would have frighted a Thief.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Where was my Son?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: He went out upon business as soon as e're you left him.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ah! curse of his Journey! this is one of his tricks.
I thought what a Son I had got: send a Hue and Cry after him
Presently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Pray do not wrong him:
I know his Noble Mind's so truly vertuous, that should he
Hear of your suspitions: he'd blush to death for shame,
Not of himself, but you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: He Sir? No, Sir, y'are mistaken in Mr. Manley: I'm sorry
You should injure so worthy a Gentleman: I warrant he
Forgot to shut the door, and some body 'een slipt in
And stole away all.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: This was your fault too, you Baggage; would
You have such a Treasure in your Chamber, and dare to sleep?
You never learn't that of me, I'm sure.

div.stage: To them Hazzard in a Fume.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O, here's the Gentleman himself now: you shall see
What he'l say to you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: 'Tis not he sure, if he were guilty, he durst not face me gain.

You Housewife, hear you:
Aside to Mrs. Manley.
Not a word of what I said.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Be confident, Sir, I respect both your Honours
And your Safeties more high then to reveal it.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Where is this drunken Dog? with a Pox to him! must my
Business be neglected for his afternoons Drinkings? Prithee

Sweet forgive me,
To Mrs. Manley.
I did not see thee, my impatience hoodwinks me.
Where is this Villain?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Whom mean you Dear?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: This careless Rascal.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Whom Son?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Thus he serves me always when my occasions require
Greatest haste; he must be Tipling.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Good Son, tell us whom.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: He's monstrous angry!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Why, my negligent Rascal Iack; I hope, Thomas,
You would not detain him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By my troth, I saw him not this Evening, nor heard
Of him, till when you bid him make haste after you.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Is he not in the House then? now do not I know
Where to find him without a Conjurer; the Rogue
Has got my money too: Thirteen hundred pound in Gold,
And without that, I am —

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ha! then I smell Knavery, had he so much of yours?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: He wanted not a grain of the sum.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: As sure as can be, this Fellow is run away with all.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: No: do not think so: alas! he was Cashier unto my Uncle:

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And, methinks now to you.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: I dare swear, his innocence in that point's equal
With mine.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Nay, be not over confident, for we are robb'd too.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Robb'd!

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Yea, verily, robb'd, all my Plate is run away, and
Your Wives Jewels.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: It could be none but he, for I mist him presently
After your departure.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Nay, then I am confuted: O! these Knaves that can be so
False hearted! do they think there is no Hell, Father?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O, good Son, do not put me in mind of Hell!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: But has the Rogue taken all?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: All but my Wedding Ring, Love.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Nay, if that be safe, it's no matter for the rest:
We have more Jewels in my Ships.
Come, Sir, be not dejected, leave the melancholy;
Send it after the Thief, let it pursue his Conscience
Like a Hue and Cry: but what an afront 'twill be unto
My Credit, To have it said for a slight thousand pounds,
Manley was fain to beg help of a Broker.
O! I'm transported!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Dear Sir, be calmer, that may be soon repaired.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: O! never! never!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Sweet Love, command your temper.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Shall my Factors send double Letters for so small a trifle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: He marks me not; good Father, do you speak
To him: his duty will not let him use you so.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What ails you Son? can you be patient at a certain
Loss? and care to think you must do that which Knights
And Lords do, borrow: I, and glad too if they can have credit.
You shall not stray for such a Sum; I'le be your Scriv'ner
And your Usurer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: O my dear Father!

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thomas, go; go fetch a Thousand pounds from
My house. Thomas goes out.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: How shall I defer this? for ought you know Sir, he's
One whose tongue is taught to speak lyes to
Gull you: this is too great a Trust to repose in any one person.
Oblige me but with your company, down stairs, and
There I'le give you Security for't, Ile not finger one penny else.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Well; I will not force you to do this; but yet
You may, Son, for mortality sake; for I protest, the
Reason I go with you, is not for Jealousie of you,
But to bear you company. Thomas returns with a Bag.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Here 'tis in Gold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come will you walk Son, we'l take a Sculler at the
Next stairs.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: I'le wait on you; my Dear, once more Farewel He goes out
This night will be the longest of our stay.
Thomas, get you gone to Justice Fowler for a Warrant,

And lay after my Renegado.
Mrs. Manley goes out.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will Sir. If I catch him, I'le make him piss Vinegar for
Stealing the Silver Chamber-pot. Ah, Rogue! no mercy of
A Young Gentlewoman. He goes out.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Now, after my new Father-in-law —His
Covetousness to have Security for his Thousand pounds,
Has made him willing to go with me to my Ship;
Where I will first clap him under Hatches, and then
Return and plunder him to a Joyn'd-stool,
It is decreed; Nor shall thy Fate, Old Man, resist my Vows.

div.head: SCENE Learcuts House.
div.stage: Enter Hazzard wet, Mrs. Manley runs to embrace him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Dear Sir, Welcome, you have almost

Outgone my wishes.
where's my Father! Ha! he weeps; nay, then He weeps.
My heart misgives me.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Oh! My eyes will better relate the Story then my
Tongue, which newly scap't the danger, trembles with fear,
And hardly yet can stammer my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manley.
sp.l: Sir, the certainty of your safety will
Keep me alive whatever you relate.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Alas! the Story's short: Your Father's dead. He would needs take water in a Sculler; And to save part of the Charges, going to row, overturned the Boat upon a Buoy: he had a thousand Guinneys in his pocket, which were too powerful for his Age, so his money weigh'd him down, and Heaven knows whither it has carried him. You may well think I did what I was able to have saved him; but it was his destiny! Yet he had the comfort, which no other Usurrer ever had, to have his Gold go with him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Miserable woman! my sorrows never end!
But as some pass by, others succeed,

More bitter then the former.
She goes out with Isbel.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Beshrew his Heart for't!
For, trust me, Sir, you discourse finely; methinks I
Shall desire to hear you often, you have
In a short time altered me much. She goes out.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Peace dwell in your soft brest! Io! She's mine.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Now what would this whining fellow have? How now, Thomas, you hear the sad News Thomas?

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I heard it to my grief, for having to no purpose search'd all day after your Man, I went in a Melancholly humour to the labour in vain, and condoling your Worships misfortune over two pots of Ale, a dismal voice Croaked out, my Masters death. Oh, Oh, Oh!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Alas poor Thomas, we must all die!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
I have heard a great many say so, but they were all▪ Parsons, Sir, Yet now me thinks I believe it too: And Die of such a death, Sir, and in such a place, where he shall never be at rest, but rowl up and down with the Tide, till one ravenous Fish make a Leg of him travel on an errand to Bermudos,
another lead him by one Arm to China, Oh it is lamentable, and makes me continually cry and howl.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Troth, Thomas I pitty thee, thou drivel'st notably,
Why dost not get thee a bib?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: I have bespoke one, Sir, and a dozen of Muckanders.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Look who knocks at door.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I Sir, who's there?

sp.speaker: Vnderwit.
sp.p: Is Mrs Manly within?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, please to come in.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: Save you, Sir, is your name Mr. Manly?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, to serve you.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: I'm glad to see you safe, Sir, but the Corps of the old man you left behind you was taken up at the Isle of Doggs, his body lay 'oth' shore as I passed by there. I was inform'd he was your Father in Law.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: He was Sir.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: Understanding his Relation to a Gentleman of your Nobleness, my Piety commanded me to cloath him in a wooden Suit, and bring him hither to you.

sp.speaker: Tho,
sp.p: I will go kiss him all over e're he's buried.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: Spare your pains, Sir, 'twill be unnecessary, for the Coffin is nail'd up, and hoop'd with Iron.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: You have shewed much Humanity in this Action. Sir, I beseech you, do not rob us of your company, till you have Finish'd that civility you have begun, leave him not now, till you have left him in the Earth.

Take Order for his Funeral this Night, we must make hast with him to perform the Will of the Dead, which was ever You know to save Tavern Charges; invite all the Neighbours, and all's Acquaintance to assist our mourning; will you please to follow?

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p:
I wait on you.
Haz. and Vnderw. go out.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Doleful imployment!
How will I gnaw the sweet-meats in my fury!
Out eat a Justice, and out drink a Jury. Exeunt.

div.head: SCEN. I. Mr. Manley newly Landed.
div.p:
WHat a Megrim I have in my head! The world is very merry, as I passed along the Trees and Hills danced Trenchmore. Catch me at Sea again, and divide me among the Mackrel, hang me, if the tempest be not yet in my brains, well I'm glad I'm at my Journeys end. I hope Hazard hath thriven well, I was impatient to know it, and that made me hasten speedily after him; here's the Cloyster where my Wife's mew'd up, and that the door where those lights are! what's the matter tro? Those Torches speak a Funeral, pray heaven she be safe.
A Drawer passes over the Stage with Pottle Pots.
I'le ask, it is less difficult to bear a danger, then 'tis to instruct it; come hither boy, whose buried from that House?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: 'Tis Mr. Learcut Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p: Ha, boy! prethee speak that again.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: 'Tis Mr. Learcut.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: There's a Crown for thy News boy. Gives money

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir, would you please to know any thing else I can tell you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Yes prethee, how, and when died he?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: He was Drown'd yesterday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: I'm sorry—'twas no sooner. Aside.
How hath he disposed of his Estate?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Troth Sir, I know not but I heard my Master say, his Daughter was to have all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: There's an Angel boy. Gives money.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Sure the Gentleman's distracted. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Sirra, I'le set thee up, Rogue, thou shalt be free of Guild-Hall. I'le change thy Apron into a Gold-Chain; thou shalt talk to Gentlemen with thy Hatt on, come tell more good news, how does his Daughter resent it.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: What's that Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p: How doth she base it Knave?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Very sadly, 'tis said Sir, and the servants of the house say she would do much worse, but that she is cheer'd up by her Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Ha Boy!

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: By her Husband Sir, that came very rich from beyond Sea lately.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Give me my money again boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Excuse me for that Sir, my Father was a Gentlemans Falconer, and he told me the first Principle of Hawking was Hold-fast, if you are upon that lock, Farwell Sir.
He offers to run away. Mr. Manly catches him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Nay, friend, I shall take advice from your Father too, for holding fast, and keep you here a little longer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, for heavens sake, my Master will hang me for staying.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: And Ile cut your throat, if you offer to stir; this shakes me, if Hazard have served me an old trick of Trustees, and entr'd my Freehold for his own use. I'm rarely serv'd—yet if he would have don't, I have such high proofs of her Loyalty I know't impossible! Yet woman though she be a fine thing must be charily kept from touching, or she will crack like a China dish, with a little blow. It may be he hath assur'd her of my death, and so hath wrought her well, be what will, I am resolv'd I'le not appear till the solemnity be over, come Sirrah, get me a room where I may see the Funeral march by, her'es t'other Crown for you.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I Sir, with all my heart, but beg pardon of my Master for me, hee'l rant like a Corporal.

div.head: SCEN. II. In Learcut's-House.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: MAke hast up to Isbel quickly, there's an old toothless Lady that feels the Burnt-Wine needs no chewing, has mumbled the Silver Flaggon full, and calls for more still.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: And there's the Seamans wife, that sits next to her has wept out the bowl twice fill'd in telling a mournful story, how her first Husband was wrackt 'oth' sands for want of water.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: A curse on her old dun Chapps! where the Devil does she find Stowage for all she swallows?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Marry, hang her! shee's Hogs-head risen in the Waste. These women of a Dutch built are all Hold, within two inches of their Port-holes, both a low and abaft. He goes out.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Nurse, here's no body here but I now.

div.stage: Nurse Reaches a gallon pot from behind the Scenes, and sayes within.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: within, Here Andrew quickly clap this under the Stairs, and let my Son carry't home when he comes.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I warrant you, by this light, 'tis as hot as a smoothing Iron, now fill me mine speedily that I may be Jogging.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Fly, fly Andrew, they are ready to Choak for want of you, in the back Chamber there's the Grocers daughter stands licking her lipps at the empty Goblet, like a Horse founder'd upon all four, and rocks her self from one Legg to tother.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I'm there already. He's going out with his Pott.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p:
More Wine for the Lords sake, there's a Feltmakers Wife within, come out of Southwark, that inveighs against intemperance, she has sipt off my Lading in her declamation, and is now fallen into a new discourse over Andrews. I'le say this for her, she keeps close to her Text still.
Dispatch me, Nurse this Pot will hold'em some play.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: The Women are all serv'd, George into the Chamber where the Corps are, the Gentlemen will be soon run over, for they are most of 'em Sack drinkers, but have a care of the Constable, and be sure you fill him a brimmer, or hee'l call twice.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: The best way to please him, is to set the Pot to his Nose,

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Prethee Nurse, quench me with a bowl of the sweetest. I am so dry, I shall take fire else. She reaches out a Bowl from behind, and he Drinks. Truly these burials are very comfortable things, they are tricks to make men do good works after their death, here Nurse, give me my charge now a bigger bowl for the Servingmen as you love me, they have breath that will suck like whirl-pools.

div.stage: As he goes off, enter Hazard and a Footboy at the other door.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: ARt thou sure 'twas he?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Am I sure you are not he? He was in the very Cloaths you gave him first, leaning out of the Tavern window one pair of Stairs high towards the Street with a Tobacco-pipe in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
Take that for thy discovery. Gives money. —I'le make thee more famous then Columbus, boy Call Vnderwitt hither to me.
The Footboy goes out.
Is the Gentleman so hasty? Is he jealous? 'Twas an oversight in me to leave money with him. Had I only taken order for his Diet he might have stay'd there yet, and not like an unmannerly Cuckold have interrupted me in my banquet on his Spouse. Wit repair this Errour, or thou shalt for ever do pennance in durty sheets, and wast thy Treasury in writing speeches for the City Pageants (He studies) it must be so, there is no remedy.
To him Underwit. O Vnderwit, welcome, I want thy help indeed now.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Why, what new accident?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Manly's come over.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Nay, I know not how; whether in an Egg-shell, or a Man of War.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: How came the Intelligence?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: My boy going out for Torches saw him in the Tavern Window.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: All's spoil'd then, if we love our selves, let's sneak out at the back-door, with what we can take up privately, unto our Ship, and set sail.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Whence this fear? Art thou turn'd Coward lately?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Faith, I thought I was valiant once, but then I was honest, I believe I could yet make a shift to fight, but to be wafted up to Tyburn in a Land Sculler, attended with a Train of Halberdiers, Truant-prentices, seems to mee much unlike a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come, be resolute, and dare thy fate. I'le teach thee how to ward this blow, be thou but bold.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: You know though I am no Master Architect of high design. I'm an indifferent subordinate workman, and can obey directions.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Then thus, (They whisper) how lik'st thou this?
Let me hugg thee!

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.l: Hast thou never a little Cadua that follows thee!
Nothing less then a Devil could teach thee this.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Commit not Sacriledge to Mercury;
Nor rob him of his honour, he's the God of Coyners boy, and
Sublimates a wit.
He flies into my fancy when I'm mov'd there.
Away, about it quickly. They go out severally.

div.head: SCEN. IV. The Street.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p:
WHat a deal ado is here about a Fellow rais'd from a Whole-sale Cheese-monger to be a Merchant, and Match into a Noble Family! What a Melody the Peckled boys of Christ-Church made! A Herald Usher'd the Hearse forsooth, and after that a mourning Serving-man with a Crest. Thomas succeeded him with a Helmet instead of a Butter Firkin, next marcht his Hearse beset with Funeral Scutcheons (Azure on a Fez Argent, three Tortoises, in chief as many Plates, which are by interpretation, three Holland-Cheeses on a Stall, and the Suffolk on a Shelf) in the rear of this came my Spouse, supported by my Benefactor, with a Pox to him, and after him the whole crew of Billingsgate and Wapping.
To him Haz. leading Mrs. Manly in mourning and Isbel. Oh, here they are returning, now I will salute 'em.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Dear fair one, stop those flood-gates; you o're flow,
Your health as well as beauty.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Sweet forsooth Cozen, be your self again.
To grieve that is to Capitulate with heaven.
Or repine at it, did you indent with Providence.
His Life should out last yours, thank Heaven for lending it so long; grudg not to part with what's not yours when the Owner calls for't, as the Parson sweetly told us.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: By your Leave Gallants.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.p: Sure I should know that Voice. Lifts up her vail and sinks.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do you know me Madam: Sure you are not so over-grown in Tears, but your Eye may discern whether you know me then:

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'le satisfie you briefly. Sir, I ne're till now beheld you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No Sir, I am her Husband.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: If any former Contract do Intitle you to make a claim, do it by Law, Our Marriage cancels it, let the Church decide the Controversie.

sp.speaker: Isbel.
sp.p: Sir, forbear you are uncivil, if you have ought to say, Do it by your Proctor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do you think I'le be talk'd out of my wife?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Your Wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I my Wife ravished by thee.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Call for a Beadle hear to conduct this Madman to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do, and bid him bring a whip with him, why thou base Impostor with what forehead darest thou deny these evidident truths: canst thou deny thy promise made to me for my re-establishment in my Estate, and now instead of that, ransak'st my rich Treasure, thou perjur'd Trayterous Villain.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: These fowl words I know not how to answer.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: In tearms as scurrillous, but the Laws shall revenge my silence, i'le provide you a Desk with a window to peep out at, where exalted above the Vulgar, you may declame to the Admiring Porters.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis a place i'le not dis-sease you of, y'are heir apparent to the Pillow; and in great probability to inherit a more lofty tenement near Padington.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: You look as you would take a room there.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Counterfiting my person makes it yours by the Statute, Did you supply my wants to begger me, your Charity was a Plot I see.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What means that Orlando furioso, is the Moon at full that he raves thus? Your name is Tom.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is it so, and you would make it Fool: but e're we part you'l find I've wit enough to prove you a Knave; you are Mr. Manly I hear Sir, whose rich Uncle died lately, and left you an Armado of rich Indian Ships.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: The very same Sir, would you serve him; bring a Certificate that you'l bid none but your self: and that you can keep Close— at Dinner time, and I may be wrought to bestow a pide Coat upon you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It would be better Husbandry to provide your self with a Clean Night-Cap, that go out like —

sp.speaker: Tho.
