sp.p: Will sorrow be buried with him: Now must I wriggle my self into my young Mistrisses favour; bless me Sir, you have chang'd Clothes very speedily!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: O here's one will dash thee,
Know'st thou me Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Know you, Sir, 'tis not so long since I saw you, that I should forget you, d'you think I do not know you because your habits alter'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Now, Sir, are you meditating an escape?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O Sir, I cry you mercy, I took you for Mr. Man. To Man.

But I see I'm mistaken.
runs to Hazard.
I have bin with the Ringers, Sir, They are strong Knaves and have pull'd out a piece from me.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
Now, Sir, are you in contemplation which is the nearest way to Bridewell.
To Mr. Manly directed.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Heres an impudent Fellow would perswade me I am not my self.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p:
Is he of the Conspiracy too? Sirrah, dare you deny that I am her husband?
Takes Tho. Violently by an Arm.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Dar'st thou deny she is my Wife.

div.stage: Takes him as eagerly by the other.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, Truly gentlemen not I.
But I am sure this is Mr. Manly, Points to Hazard.
For I saw him in Bed with his Wife this morning, and help't to dress him in these very Cloathes, and indeed la, I think you are he too, to Manly.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Are you not well.
She faints again, I'le cut her Lace, run up to the Cabinet, and fetch some Spirits somebody?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I saw a Goldsmiths boy slit a shilling once, and the Stamp was vissible on both parts:
Hath no body serv'd you so Sir? To Hazard.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
Why Reason we with one that wants it thus, in the mean time neglecting her; forgive me Sweetest,
Runs to Mrs. Man.
come help here, Thomas, her eyes open.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Bow her this way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.l: Prithee, let me prop my self with thy neck, O
Villain thou hast ruin'd me— To Haz. in his care
And on my Name stuck an eternal infamy.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: I, dear Lov, thou shalt have any thing, give her more strong-waters, drink till th'rt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.l: Drunk, and then I may be impudent! O whither shall I turn me? Aside.
If I am Just, I blast my fame for ever!
If I conserve my fame, my Faith's abandon'd.
To be a Loyal Wife I must proclaim my self She weeps.
A Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l:
As I live, she begins to waver, do you hear
Whispers to Mrs. Man.
Renounce him stiffly, or you know with what Tittle
The Town will qualifie you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: It must be so. I must abominate a real Vertue,
That unto Vulgar eyes I seem unspotted.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Still weeping forsooth Cozen?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Pray rescue me from the impertinencies
Of that babbling brawling Fellow yonder.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Wee'l into your Chamber, there repose upon the Couch.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Such strange impudence I never heard of.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Will you vanish Sir? Do not disturb the quiet of this dwelling with your unmanner'd railings, had you come in a fair civil way you had bin welcome, and might have bin drinking with the Servingmen.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Friend, pray be moderate, if all this stir be for a Cup of burnt Wine, go home and fetch your Dish▪ and the Porter shall bring it out to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Is't not enough to be gull'd, but I must be jeer'd too? Draws.

div.stage: As he is Drawing comes Vnderwit and Snippe, With three Watchman.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: That's he with the drawn Sword.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Come neighbours, let us steal behind him softly, softly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: How now, what mean you?

div.stage: Snip and his Watch seize on Mr. Man.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: What! does he resist? Take away his Sword and knock him down Neighbours for a sawcy fellow! Not obey Officers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Wherefore do you pinnion me? I am no condemn'd Rogue.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: No, not yet, but you may be in good time, let's away with these Pick-pocket Thieves, neither I, nor my Subjects can sleep on the stalls a night quietly for 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.l: I do not think but this is he that stole away my
Lanthorn, I dreamt of him presently after.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: I, and I warrant you, he had my Bill too. Sirrah confess.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man:
sp.p: Is all the City Mad?

sp.speaker: 3 Wat.
sp.p: No Neighbour, I see he has no grace in him; he will not confess.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Let me but know my crime, and I'le obey your Wooden Power.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: How now, Malepert Rascal! Talk to Mr. Constable, Kemb his Head with a Halbert.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: No, Neighbour, patience, I will give him leave to speak; he has but a short time, his breath will be stopt suddenly, alas friend 'tis no great fault y'are accus'd of; 'tis only flat Felony, taking a purss upon Shooters-hill; that's all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Who I? Let me see my accuser, I know he'l acquit me.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Oh, are you one of that Fraternity! he came hither, Thomas, upon some design, is the Plate safe?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: There was a silver spoon missing Yesterday, it may be he has it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p: Let me but view the party robb'd.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p:
There he is, Sir,
Points to Underwit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Oh! are you the man? then I smell whence this wind blows, you are that Cheaters Complice, when you robb'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Is Yesterday seven-night, so long ago you have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: What did I spoil you of? your vertues? or one bale of high men, and another of low? Forty copper Rings, and one gold one to put of the rest off?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Yes, those very things, besides twelve pounds in silver. How readily he can tell the number! Gentlemen, remember he has confest the gold ring.

sp.speaker: Sn. & Wa.
sp.p: I, I, I wee'l bear witness, come, hale him away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: By heaven I'm abus'd! I came but this night from Sea.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Oh, Sir; These excuses will not serve.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Take but that Fellow along with me in the mourning Cloak, he's the arrant'st Cheat—

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: How now, Sawcebox! what! abuse Mr. Manly? away, away with him, he's an arrant Knave I warrant you.

div.stage: All goe out but Haz▪ and Tho.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Did you ever see such an impudent Rogue, Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Never since I was born Sir, but me thinks he's very like you good Sir, let me bite a mark about your face, that I may know you. Thom. goes out.

div.head: SCEN. V. A Chamber.
div.l: TO what a Precipice do you hurry me,
My wicked thoughts! O whether am I reeling!
Why did I not acknowledge my delusion?
Then I had yet been white in my own innocence:
Whereas this rash black act of my denying him,
Stains me all over with incontinence.
Now I perceive sins do not walk alone;
But have long trains, endless concomitants,

Who acts but one will soon commit a Million.
Enter Hazard.
He comes again, this ravisher of my honour,
And yet; I know not why, I cannot hate him!
Would he could put on some less pleasing form;
I am not safe in this — But I must Muster
All I have left of vertue to resist him.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Peace to your fair thoughts, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: It must come then, by some other Messenger.
Thou art the Screech-owl to, the bird of night
That bod'st nought but ill: Why do'st thou follow me!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Why do you fly me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Because thou Breath'st infection on me: thou art
A Pestilence (or should'st be!) to my Nature.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: If I'm infectious, 'tis alone with Love;
And then no wonder, if like those who bear
Contagion about 'em, I desire
To infect you with the same Disease!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: I bear thy spots already in my Fame;
And they are Mortal to it.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: They are not visible:
And so long, all conclude you may be cur'd
I can bring Cordials to restore your honour,
But you shun your Physitian.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: No, my Condition's desperate; 'tis past help.
I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: How many Women whose names stand white in the Records of Fame, have acted willingly what you were wrought by fraud to suffer; only they keep it from the publique knowledge, and therefore they are innocent. How many Fair ones, were this your story acted in a Play, would come to see it sitting by their Husbands, and secretly accuse themselves of more. So full of spots and brakes is humane life, but only we see all things by false lights, which hide defects, and gloss 'ore what's amiss, —Grant me your Love once more, and I will yet restore your Honour: You shall appear as vertuous and innocent, as you are fair and charming.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: How dar'st thou move so impudent a Suit,
Or hope the least success in't! Can I think
Of all Mankind thou canst restore my Honour;
Thou Thief, thou Murtherer, thou destroyer of it.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: I grant I am a Thief, and who so proper
To give Wealth, as he who robb'd you of it?
But I have not destroy'd it: 'tis it safe,
And does not that deserve some recompence.
Love me, and let me get a new possession
From knowledge of that good your Error gave me,
And you shall see what—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: Never, name it no more; no prayers shall ever win me.
No Sophistry seduce, or Tortures force me.
To one dishonest act, now known dishonest!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: What contrary effects enjoyment causes!
In you a loathing, and in me a love!
The sence of such a blessing once possest,
Makes me long after what before I priz'd not!
And sure that needs must be the truest passion,
Which from possession grows; for then we know
Why 'tis, and what we love: all love before,
Is but a guess of an uncertain good,
Which often, when enjoy'd we find not so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Why am I forc'd to tell you that I love you!
I do, and blush to say it; but my guilt
Shall reach no farther than my selfe; expect
No fruit from my Confession, no new yielding.
Yet love me still— for that I may permit you;
Think of no other woman for my sake,
And I'le forgive you what is past: and sometimes
More then I should remember you!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: And is this all that I must ever hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manley.
sp.l: This is too much!
Have pitty on me, and demand no more:
Leave me some Love for him who should have all:
And, if you have so much of honour in you,
Invent some means to piece my shatter'd Fame.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Madam, I will not shame your Charity:
You have forgiven me, and I'le deserve it:
I'le give you from my self; though I can ne're
Forget you have been mine: You have left in me
An hatred to all woman kind besides,
And more undone me in this short visionary joy
Of once possessing, then I e're could you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.l: Then Farewel!
Farewel the mutual ruine of each other:
Farwel a dream of Heaven; how am I tost
Betwixt my duty and my strong desires!
Dash't like a ship, upon an unseen Rook;
And when my care can hardly get my off:
Yet I am ready to repeat my crime;

And scarce forbear to strike a second time.
Exeunt severa •• y.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: How now, what News from Tripoly?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, 'tis no jesting matter, my Mistress is in the strangest taking, she fomes as if she had the falling sickness, Curses like a Carman stopt going up Ludgate-Hill, and has whetted the point of her Steel bodkin, as if she had a plot on us, she has askt twice or thrice for a Knife.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Never fear her, I warrant you, she that will ask for a weapon is not desperate; get you gone in to her, and twattle her out of the sullens if you can; if not, I'le not long be absent.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: I have done the business, the Justice was as stately as a drunken Constable at midnight, till his Clark whisper • d him in the Ear what I had brought him, and told him of your promise of a Turky Pye at Easter, then the weight of that made him lean to my party, and now he has committed him to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Thomas (Thom. within) Sir? (Hazard) away to the Jaylour, grease him in the Fist, desire him to be the new Prisoners Sen • p • ter, and bestow Cuffs on him.

Vnderwit, a Word. We must break up house-keeping presently, and away; for this Woman's plaguy peevish, and will discover all: go abroad quickly, wee'l to Sea to Night, though I am monstrous loth to leave Her.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, for I spi'd one of the Sailours in a Strong-Water Shop, who tells me another Ship fell fowl of our • , and has broke her Stern and Galleries.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Then we are lost!

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: No, not so; I'le help you out, so that we may scape gainers, though not so great ones as we aimed to be. I thought on my expedient in my return from the Justices, and least my memory might fail me, writ it down: There 'tis, (gives him a Paper) you know Manly's credulous enough to believe a formal story, And while you prepare the woman; if I work not his dull clay brain to any thing, I am no Master Potter.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I like the design, let us about it presently; and with the Morning-Tide, down to the Ship. They go out.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Neighbours, I am a Searcher by my Place, and a Constable by my Office; you are my Trusty boys, that Watch my Candle, and take a care that I do not sleep in the dark. I am not ignorant of your abilities, for every night I'm on the Watch, you overcome eighteen penny-worth of my Ale apiece, besides what Thieves allow that they may steal by us, and our extortions from wandring Wastcoateers, with all which you are yet able to reel home in the mornings, which shews, you have not only able Legs (and those I have seen you use very nimbly when you have been assaulted by drunken Gentlemen) but strong Brains, wherefore Neighbours I ask your advice concerning this Warrant.
Pray Mr. Constable, whose Warrant is it.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: By' Lady, that's a hard question, for a Justice of Peace with the help of his Clark made it, my Gossip Turnup paid for it, and she delivered it to me.
I but I mean Mr. Constable, from what Justice came it?

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Why it came from Justice Shipwrack, a very able man: I know not what rent he sits at, but that he paid a good fine for his place, it cost him a brace of hundreds to be put into Commission— but to the business — my Gossip that gave it me, told me it was a Warrant; but we Magistrates must not trust too much to Information. I cannot read it Neighbour, pray do you.
Truly, 'tis a very pretty thing, how evenly 'tis cut!
Hold up t'other end Neighbour.
Why, will you teach me to read?

No truly, I will not teach you to do that I cannot do my self; but I know you hold it as if you were about to shew tricks with the heels upwards. Well, this is from the purpose how do you like the Warrant?
Very handsomely indeed, Mr. Constable, these dainty fair black stroaks look very prettily upon the white Paper.
Lord! To see what some men can do! How many scratches go to the making of a Warrant!

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Well, but what are the Contents?
Nay, there I leave you. I should have learn'd to write and read too, had not all my time been taken up in running of Errands.
Give it my neighbour here, he was Clerk of a Parish once, and might have been still, had he not frighted the Patron out of his sleep with Tuning a Psalm. He has his Written-Hand at his Fingers ends.
I Neighbour, I can spy the business through these thick Spectacles. These are — He reads.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: What are they Neighbour?
A Warrant I'le lay my life on't.
Patience, good Mr. Constable to will and Command you—

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: I and you too, Neighbours, I'le not go else, do you think I'm mad, to be duckt alone?

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Well, one.
And Command you to —

sp.speaker: Snip,
sp.p: Nay, by'r Lady, all four or none I say again.

sp.l: Observe Mr. Constable—
To make strict Search —

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: I promise you I'le be strict enough.
And Enquire—

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.l: Wee'l enquire into every Hogshead in the Ship.
No Vessel shall scape unsearcht, even to the very
Aqua Vitae Bottle.

sp.p: In all suspitious places—

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Hold, Neighbour, here is a very suspitious house hard by old Mrs. what do you call's, that whiffes whole pots of Ale off, and cries Dam me you whore, pledge the Gentleman— Super naculum, or I'le fling the remainder on your Satin-gown▪ She's a good one I warrant her, had not we best look there?

Indeed Mr. Constable, she's a vertuous Matron, pays Church duties justly though she make no use of it, and does a great many Charitable deeds in the Parish, she took a likeing to my daughter, because she was somewhat handsome, and keeps her I warrant you, in goodsilk gowns by'r Lady all the Term time.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Read on then.
Namely in the Ship called the William.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Mark that Neighbour.
Yes my namesake.
Riding about Cuckholds Haven.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Remember that Neighbour, that we do not forget whither we are to go.
Ne'er doubt it, I call to mind a very good token, a Shipwright got my eldest boy there in a Lanthorn of the great Ship.
For the Child of Widdow Turnup — O Young Rogue! steal already.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: No, Neighbour, you misconceive that Child, for he is stol'n poor fool, some Knave or other has ticed him away with a baked Pair, and my Gossip hear's this Ship is bound for the Bermudos, and suspects he may be spirited into it, truly Neighbours consider soberly, and 'tis a very hard case, when we cannot get Children our selves, but are forc't to allow wages to Seamen, and labouring younger brothers to do it for us, and as soon as ever we have 'em they must be stollen, there's all our charges meerly throne away.
Does any body steal Children?

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Yes, familiarly when they have poor folks bratts, the Church-wardens wink at such small faults; nay, and some think (under the Rose neighbours) 'tis done by their own Journeymen.

I would fain be acquainted with these Child-stealers. I have a Litter of my little Urchins at home, I'le shew 'em how they shall steal them every one, and their mother too if they please, but then they must come in armour, for she's a plaguy Jade, and will kick woundily.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: On, On.
All persons whom you shall instruct, to bring before me, require in all persons to be aiding and assisting unto you —

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: That's some comfort yet.
Fail not at the Execution hereof—
Execution! What? have we more power to hang, draw, and quarter with 'em, but we cannot hang 'em, read that over again Neighbour.
Fail not the execution hereof on your peril.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: I, There's the sting in the Tail of all Warrants, we must execute other mens wills on our own perils, while they snort in security.
By the Mass, this is a dangerous business indeed! these Marriners are boistrous Knaves.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: We must even through stich with it. I have made my Will, and took my leave of my Wife and Children; let's run to the Alehouse and say prayers over a double pot, and then we may venture the more boldly by the time, Tide will serve.

Yes, Mr. Constable, but pray let's make all the haste you can, for you know the Warrant saies the Ship is now riding about Cuckholds-Haven; but if it rides but a Trot or a hand gallop, it may be twice as far off e're morning.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Do not be afraid of that Neighbour, for while it turns round about it, it ever now and then comes into the same place again; and there certainly we shall find it, for it dares not disobey our Warrant.

div.head: SCEN. I. A Ship or Gunroom.
div.stage: Learcut, and the Boatswain, Duke Watson.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.p: I'le give thee a Tenement of four pound, per annum and let me go to Land again.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: I'd rather lie 'ith Bilbows, then in such a Hovel; it cannot be so convenient as a Hammaque.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.p: I'le give thee Cheese to Victual thy whole Family for a Twelve moneth, though every soul were Welch.
A whole Tun of Butter to mollifie thy stony Bisket, and twenty new stampt spankers tied up 'ith corner of a Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Your Cheese is mouldy, and your Butter fusty, your old Shop-keepers stick friend.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What temper is this fellow made on! Aside.
This would have wrought me t'have sold my Father to the Turks
I must bid higher yet,
I'le give thy Wife a water'd Chamlet Petticoat,

Lac'd with embroider'd Sattin; a Gold wedding Ring for every Finger, no body shall take for less then a Midwife, she shall have a rough Demicastor with a Sugar-loaf crown; Coifs and Cross-cloaths numberless, a Silver Bodkin to rectifie her stairing hairs; new Neats-leather Shooes that creak, and murrey Worsted Stockings.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: You may as soon bribe Tempests, or with your entreaties calm rageing Seas, as tempt me.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Think the Land you see on either side to be a meer apparition.
Your sole shall not touch ground till you are in Bermudas.
If profit will not move, let pitty stir you.
Let not these gray hairs
Be subject to the mercy of a drunken,
Or domineering Planter.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: These hairs I reverence, that the honour
I pay to them may be return'd to me,
When age shall make mine such.
But, Old man, your extortions have degraded you.
Had you shewn pitty to the Needy Widow,
Y'had here not wanted it:
But to your Cabbin, see if you can sleep on't.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Set me a Shore, I'le make thee my heir.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Alas! Sir, I am too old to believe the promises of men
In distress, I am a Seaman, and have been in a storm.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: This was a kind Visit indeed to come aboard, y'are welcome to the Masters Cabbin, Captain, were he here himself, I know he'd make very much of you; for he's an old Seaman, and loves one with his life.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: Honest Boatswain, thank thee; I read thy kindness in thy eyes, before I heard it from thy mouth.

div.stage: To them Swabber with a basket of Bisket, and a Bottle of Wine, Tobacco, Pipes and Match.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Noble Captain, once more, welcome; Here's good Wine aboard, and white Bisket, in to the Cook Boy, quickly, Bid him put some Beef in the Stew-pan.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: I see it, and I taste it now.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: What we have given for such in Algiers.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: Nothing, for we had no money, had not you made your Escape, you might have staid as long as I.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: I hope we shall be able to requite their courtesies one day. I wear their mark yet. Shews his arm, and Anchor on it.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: I believe, you had but little faith in the Hieroglyphick. When they Printed it, that Anchor represented you but slender hopes of your redemption.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: No, for each flook of it put me in mind how fast I was moor'd there.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: But you took an occasion to Cut the Cable.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Yet I was strong enough to bring the Anchor with me.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: I stay'd till mine was weigh'd (I do you reason) Drinks.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: T'other spoonful, noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: Here's to your boon Voyage. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: I pledge you. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: Whither are you bound, They take Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: For Bermudas.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: Would I had never known't !

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Had you any great loss on that shoar,

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: Yes, such a one as I shall never recover. Aside.
I lost a quiet Conscience.
What store of Passengers have you aboard?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Very few yet, but we keep our Spirits hungry, and they are seeking prey in all quarters.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: How goes the Market now?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Faith low, a Crown a pole.
Fling out a rope, fling out a rope.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: Who the Divel are those coming aboard tro?
Boy what are they? A Searcher come with a Warrant to Search The Ship.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Noble Captain, pray step upon the Deck, and hold 'em in discourse over a Bottle until I give the word.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: 'Tis the least service I can do you. Goes out.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: But it is greater it may be, then you think of, what if they should come to search after this old fellow? Then there's a Ship clearly lost, I must tack about to gather wind, or I shall be driven backwards, now let me prove an able Pilot, or my designs sink, where are you, Mate? Opens the Scuttle. What think you of a little Fresh-air, give me your hand Father.

div.stage: He pulls up to him Learcut.

sp.speaker: Laercut.
sp.l: Do you mean to air me that I may keep sweet?
Or 'ist your plot I should see earth, and not to enjoy it, but to curse the want of it.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: No, but to seat you in't if you'l be wise; the last Conference I had with you has struck a deep Impression on me, and so wrought me that could I see a probability you would perform what then you promised me, you should be free as I, within two hours.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.p: Art thou in earnest?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Were you in earnest when you promis'd me to make me your heir.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.p: Yes, by —

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Nay, do not swear, but set your hand and seal to what I write here. Writes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I, I'le subscribe any thing.
I'le sign any Covenants, but never perform any Aside.
And if he sues, I'le plead per Minas to it.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Here Sir. Gives Learcut a Paper, he reads.
I do promise to adopt Iohn Whistler my Son, and settle my estate on him within these ten daies.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: That's all.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: A trifle, then here I sign and seal.
Dull blockhead! He forgets witness too Aside.
This will never hold.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Well Sir, no this is done; I'le be better then my word. I'le let you see, although I am your heir, I thirst not for for your death, I'le save your life, Sir,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Am I design'd to death then?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Without remedy, unless you take my Councel.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Honest Son!

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Here will immediately a company of Ruffians come, pretending they are Officers (although in truth they are disguis'd Rogues, hir'd by the Master to sound if you would me seek for the help of any you thought could free you from this prison.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: O Villains!

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: They'l set a face of searching the Vessel from the Keel to the Top-gallant, and it may be they will blurt out some questions to entrap you; but if you speak the smallest word, or think too lewd a Fellow with a butchers knife.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Were ever such things heard of! Twenty per Cent. is nothing to't.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Wee'l pair your weazand to the coar without any mercy.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: How happy am I that thou art honest I'le warrant 'em. Il not speak a word to 'em, I'le breath as softly as I can too.

div.stage: He fixes his eyes on the ground.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: They come now, be wise, what would you have? come upon the Quarter-deck here.

div.stage: To them Salt-eele, Snip and Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: The child was in none of those bottles we tasted was it neighbour?
No sure, for the Wine tasted very sweet.
And the bottle did not smell of Chamber-lie.
Pray Mr. Constable lets make haste, for I begin to be Sea-sick.

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: My Stomack wambles too. He spies Learcut. God bless us Neighbour! The Devil in the shape of old Mr. Lear.
Ah, ah where is he, Mr. Constable?

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: Oh, there, there, there, neighbours I think none of us can say our prayers, but I am sure we can all run.

div.stage: Snip and the Watch goe out.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: What hast they make! there's o • e of 'em tipt over into the River.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: It may be he hath need on't.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: His Comrades take little notice of it, for they are putting off without helping him. Oh the fellow has got hold of an Oar, and will not part with it, I'le go down to the Forecastle and keep sight of 'em as long as I can. Exit Salteel.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Content.
What chear?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Are they all gone?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Gone, Yes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Shall we ashoar?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Is the Boat ready?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Some three or four months hence it shall be to set you a shore in America.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Did you not promise Liberty to me,
If I would sign a Writing I deliver'd.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Yes, I did so.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: You talkt another kind of Language then.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Yes, but my meaning was the same as now.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Why, did you make me hope, but to despair?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p:
Truth, there was much necessity for it, which you'l be apt to believe, when I tell you when these Searchers came aboard,
I fear'd they had made some discovery of you, by some words you might let slip; wherefore I did apply that promise finely guilded for a preventing Pill.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Thou hast not only then deluded me, but lost thy self by't, if thou dost not yet perform it look but what an estate, I make thee heir of at least an hundred thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: There take your meat again, do not I know men in necessity are alwaies prodigal of promises? but once escap'd the storm, the Saint to whom they vow'd is laught at.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Well, Heaven thou art just! for when I made Aside. this promise I resolv'd to break it, and therefore I am paid in my own coyn, do but yet shew thy mercy in my deliverance, and here I vow a punctual observation of all promises I e'er shall make, though never so disadvantagious to me.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Noble owners, welcome aboard, now Sir you may beat your bargain with them, the old man and I have been bartering for his liberty, by the Mass he bids high.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.p: Would you be out of the Ship?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Yes any where else.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Why, be but patient till we come to the Ocean; wee'l fling you over board, and tie a good Cannon Bullet about your neck instead of a Gold Ring in your ear.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Or what think you of being turn'd loose in a half Tubb, or a Wash-bowl, like a baited Cat.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Yes, you shall have your freedom— but you shall serve for it some fourteen years among the flax-dressers in the Summer-Islands, exercise will get you such a stomack, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Is there no hope of ransome?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Yes, by sneaking out of the world to take a Nap with your Forefathers.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l: Come I interpose, and on condition you'l be tractable,
I'le prevail with this Gentleman, Sign those Articles.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Any.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: He that is so precipitate in signing any, in my opinion resolves never to keep any, though he huddle on now, hee'l put on his spectacles, I fear, when he should perform 'em.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: To clear that scruple I will swear performance,
And if I fail may he whom I invoke —

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: There's a necessity in believing him, yet still I doubt.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.p: Do not, who knows his space, dyet may have caused much mortification? shall I read 'em to you?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: With all my heart. Vnderwit reads. That you pay the Eight thousand pounds left to Mrs. Manly by her Grand-father with interest to this day to her Husband, that you bestow on me and the rest of my friends two thousand pounds for taking the pains to make you just and honest, that such as have had any hand in your Cure shall pass undamaged by any Suits from you, and indempnified from the rigour of any Laws, in Condition of which we will make restitution of all we have taken from you, together with your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: These are but reasonable, I assent to 'em,
Nay more, I thank you, and shall reckon you
My greatest benefactors, for you have
Restor'd me man, before I was a muck-worm.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: I have obtain'd my ends then, which were only to reduce you to terms of Justice.
Boatswain, this Ship's the wages of thy fidelity.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Gentlemen I thank you, and I beseech you let a friend of mine be welcome to you in her, noble Captain, be pleased to come into the Cabin.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l:
I am astonish'd — but my amazement must turn to reverence.
Kneels to Salteel.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: All things conspire to crown me happy, spare that labour,
Sir, reserve your knees for Heaven and your Parents—

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: Do you deny me then.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: No, but I beg pardon of you
My earnest Zeal to make you restitution
Will not permit me, to relate the cause of it,
Least it defer your happiness, but if you will with me—

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l: Will I? Yes into an earthquake, Mr. Learcut I beseech you dispence with me till Evening; I'le meet you then at your own House.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: With all swiftness imaginable,

Will you along Sir.
To the Boatswain.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Yes, I follow you.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l: Release the Waterman, how does he take it?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Faith very well, Sir, I've kept him drunk ever since.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.l: Give him that for the loss of his time. Gives him money.
Well, Sir, Farwell, at seven I'le be at your own home. Goes out.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Is the Boat ready now?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: It is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: To shoar with me quickly, then I shall never believe I'm there, till I feel my feet touch the ground, a comfortable Ditch in the Isle of Doggs now would confirm me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: Suppose I did believe, that on necessity
This Usurpation of my name and bed
Were to be pardon'd, that my Wife's untoucht yet.
Yet comes it in the reach of possibility
That to be dragg'd to the Goal, hither, to Newgate
To be squeez'd down into the Dungeon
Among ten thousand grey Confederates,
But a degree beneath a Pick-pocket
To be thus Manacled, next Goal-delivery
To be turn'd o'er to Tyburn for my good.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Have you but patience, and you'l grant it is;
For your harsh usage here, 'twas you that pull'd it
Upon your self, had not this trick been put on you,
Y'had ruin'd both your self and me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: Yes, I believe,
I had undone your hopes upon my Wife
But thereby built my self a goodly Fabrick
Seated full Lord of her estate.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: There's your mistake you think that she is Mistress of all Learcuts Wealth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.l: Yes, Sure.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: She hath no interest in't at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: Why have you chang'd the property, and sent it
Beyond Seas?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: No indeed. Yet she hath no right in't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Do not I know Learcut had none to give it to?
Not so much as a Gingerbread Cozen
To bestow a Ring with a Deaths-head on? is not she is Heir!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Who is then?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: No body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.l: He was no felo de se.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Very far from it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: The Man talks Riddles.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: You will find 'em truths.
Because you saw the old man buried,
You therefore do conclude him dead.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: What if I do.
That way of reasoning, once upon a time,
Was not thought much incongruous, however now
You Wits o'th' first rate disapprove it.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: 'Tis but a Fallacy, and I'le resolve it
Without the help of Logick, the old Usurer
By my contrivance was conveyed away
To a secure place; in the Interim
Your Wife and I did celebrate his Funerals,
Burying a weighty Coffin for his Worship,
Thus we resolv'd to keep him in restraint
Till we could either force him to be just,
Or re-imburse us out of his estate.
Now I have got's consent, hee'l pay you Sir,
Eight thousand pounds with interest, and receive
You into favour if you yield to this.
I would advise you to't; I will release him,
And in his liberty, you shall meet your own,
If not, I'le drown your Father in Law in earnest.
Transport away your Wife to the West-Indies.
Keep all the estate, and the next Sessions.
I'le hang you for a High-way man, I have Money,
And the City certainly can furnish me
With witnesses for good considerations.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: He talks unhappy. I must believe him, Aside
For my own safety, this choak-pare must down.
I do believe you, that my Wife's unstain'd,
If I believe amiss, I pray forgive me.
I thank you for your fine contrivances:
If you have had any closer then ordinary
With my dear Chicken thank, you for them too.
I am not the first Gentleman hath borne
A Horn in's Crest.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: To clear that Scruple,
I Swear—

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir do not, for an Oath
Will not make me believe a tittle more.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Come then, we'l walk down and discharge you instantly.
I have a Warrant here will do't, from thence,
Home to your Father-in-Laws.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: As speedy as you can, for I am
Much out of Love with this fashion of ruffle Cuffs. They go out.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.l: Day light's shut in, and yet my doors are open,
Here has been good House-keeping, I warrant you,
Since my departure, meat Usher'd up with Musick,
And all the Parish have been in the bottom
Oth' Cellar, I'le shut the door and steal in softly
To discry the behaviour of my Family. He goes out.

div.head: SCENE.
div.stage: Isbel affrighted, and Thomas holding his Breeches.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: O Lord Thomas shift for your self.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Is death such an excellent Cure for the Gout, he can walk Now. Up to my Mrs. quickly Isbel, she can say prayers.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: If he had been a mannerly Ghost he would never have Disturb'd us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This comes of not making Love in the day time, then There's ne'er a Spirit of e • m all dares shew his face.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.l: Oh! he comes again!

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What do you fear? Why do you shun me thus.
I am not Pestilential, nor Leaprous.
Gone without answering, is this House mine?
Sure I'm on Ship-board, yet my giddy brains
Have play'd the Carpenters and built these Houses.
Now, me thinks some body knocks at door, One knocks.
And now, methinks I open it. He opens the door.
And now, my thinks, here is a boy, I cannot dream
All this, what would you have boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I should speak with Mr. Manly, Sir,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Me thinks he speaks too.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: He bid my Master send in his Bill to Night, and I have brought it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What is thy Master boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A Vintner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Hey day! My years store exhausted in two dares,
I'le examine this boy farther, For what Wine is't boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: For the Burnt-Clarret, Sir, at Mr. Learcuts Funeral.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Ha, boy! is he buried; if he be, they have not laid weight enough on him to keep him under ground, for I am he boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Ha, is the Devil so well pleas'd at a Usurers Burial, that he comes in person to defray the charges, bless me! I see his Cloven foot now, sure he cannot run as fast with that as I with mine. Runs out.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: How now, the boy is fled too? it seems then I am dead and buried, and bring my own Ghost to fright 'em, this is very pretty. I have a fine Daughter in the mean time, that this conspires against me, well, I will prosecute my adventure, and since you have made me an Inhabitant of the lower Region. I'le ramble through every Room, and play some fair Tricks among you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you check these swelling Torrents of my amazement, lest the Lawless Flood pull up my sences by the roots; Why, do you deny to accept that duty you have hitherto smil'd on, when e're I tender'd?

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: Can you pardon my Usurpation of your bended knees,
When you shall know that I am not your Father?

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l: It is a knowledge I should never thirst after,
But with more fervent prayers wish, I may
Continue in an ignorance I doat on:
Yet, if it be your will to cast me off,
I shall submit to it, and who 'ere
You turn me over for a Son unto,
My thoughts shall still acknowledge you my Father.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: Some Five and twenty Years are past, since setting forth
A Ship for the Bermudas, and employing
My Agents (people commonly called Spirits)
To furnish me for my Plantation
With such as were to inhabit it, one of 'em
Brought you unto me in your Nurses armes.
I Shipt you both with me your Foster Mother
Dyed in the Voyage of a Calenture.
Seeing you destitute, and with my self
Considering I had made you so, my heart
Immediately was fill'd with Love and Pitty.
I carefully provided for your health,
And when you were ripe for generous education,
You wanted not what I could help you to.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.l: You have by this astonishment given me occasion
To be inquisitive, pray be not offended
If I ask why, till now you neer disclos'd
This weighty secret to me.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: I was so proud of you,
That I resolv'd no man should lay claim to you
Unless my self; you may remember I
With swelling eyes upon your Cheeks did leave
My parting Tears in Holland, where I last left you.
You know, I then was a Captain of a Ship
I'th Fleet bound for Brazile in the States service
When a stout Turkish Squadron master'd them,
Then were we Fettered all and sent to Algier,
Where we were us'd with utmost Barbarisme.
Then penitence instructed my moist eyes
To wash my sins in Tears. I did so, vowing
(If I ever were free) as far as possible
To make you reparation; gentle Heaven,
Having a care of you, preserved me,
For about six months since, I was redeemed
Mongst others by the Publique Charity.
We now wear the accomplishment of my penitence,
For to some House adjacent y'are indebted
For your birth, your father will be easier found,
And when we know him,
Hee'l make no scruple to acknowledge you,
After he views the Evidence, I bring with me:
But we burn day-light, and defer your blessing▪
Let us enquire.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Hear are discoveries,
More worth the Note then those of the new World. They go out.

div.head: The SCENE, Learcut's House.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.l: Have you leapt out of your Senses?
Are you possess'd?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. send for a Cunning Man.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Isbel, hide me under your Petticoats, that the Divel may not find me, they say he dares not peep under a Maids Coat.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Are you Lunatick?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.p: What strange Monster have your fancies been brought to Bed of?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: O Lord Mrs. he leapt in the Key-hole, he has got Firebrands instead of eyes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I, and he draws a great Chain after him▪

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Is not the Monkey broke loose?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I will believe now? Now he's playing his pranks in the Kitchin, hee'l be in the Closset among Clatering among the Pewter. Your Sweetmeats and glasses presently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.p: What should that noise be tro?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Ten to one but the Cats are shewing Christmas gambals.

sp.l: Do I speak truth yet? good Spirit do not pick my bones,
I am but lean, and not food good enough for an old Divel.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Spare me, I beseech you good Mr. Belzebub.

sp.speaker: Laercut.
sp.p: Fear not t'approach me, for I am yet alive, rumour was somewhat too hasty to kill me, and some of my friends over pious to bury me before I was cold, but I forgive all.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: What Miracle's this? The Emblem of an Apostate? The Spirit tun'd flesh. Mrs. Man. embraces Mr. Learcut.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: This is comfortable News, I'm sure it makes the Spirits return to my flesh.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: I'm afraid still, prithee Thomas Chear me up.

Madam I now at length present him to you, whose shadow I did represent—
Brings Manly to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcom.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p: Do you know me now then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Manly.
sp.p: Sir, I hope this Gentleman your Friend, hath explain'd that to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.l: Yes, and all scruples are vanish'd now,
And yet I hear the worst betwixt you. Aside,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
How's this? are not you my Son in Law, Sir,
To Hazard.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir I only attempted your conversion in my Friends behalf.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: But you were my Daughters Bed-fellow in his behalf.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Friend, That's a mistake too,
She's free from any unchast touch of me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Manly.
sp.p: Very likely. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Well then my true Son in Law, welcome, I will not fail a Syllable of my promises.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: Use Exercise, as playing at Cards, or Shuttle-Cock, do any thing rather than be idle; and at night when you undress your self against the fire, chafe in three or four short pithy prayers and the deeds done.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Why look you, Madam, to let you see how far I am from a desperate Inamorato, I promise you faithfully I will never trouble you with this Sugar Courtship while I live, if on these terms you please t'accept my Visits, they shall be frequent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.p: Most willingly, for I affect your Conversation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Well Thomas, I remit your errours; but have a care you prove true to me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Else may my Pigs ney, here forsake her Trusty Thomas!

div.stage: To them Underwit, Salteel, and Boatswain.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.p: Lo're your Top-gallant, you must stick here Sir.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l: I do with all obedience, and beg your Pardon Sir,

For those discoveries I put you upon.
Kneels to Learcut.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Why to me all this?
Do you begin to feel compunction,
And now come to restore?

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.p: I do so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: Withal, I here make restitution too,

A son that six and twenty years ago was stol'n from you by some whom I employ'd; a Crime I hope heaven hath forgiven; if you cannot, here do I wait my doom: (Nay do not stand so like a
Statute, 'tis a truth I publish.) This gentleman an Infant was brought to me in his Nurses Arms, about his Neck this Whistle which I have kept like Meleagers brand.

sp.speaker: Learcut.
sp.l: This is the same, now I am compleatly happy
Ev'n ready for my Tombe, and only Thirst
To live in thee.

sp.speaker: Vnder.
sp.l: May you live long and happy,

Dear Sister—
Runs and embraces Mrs. Learcut.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: This Act of yours Cancels my anger. To Salteel.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: You are kindly charitable.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: The Brother and Sister are very intimate, and loving already; small kindred are not taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Vnderw.
sp.p: Sister Excuse me, If I lay claim to my new Priviledge, I fear I have assisted an exploit will shame us both. Nay do not blush but tell me, Did Hazard e're enjoy you?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: How do you like the new revived Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: In truth, he looks like a fine Fellow to make a Husband of.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Sister, I am much taken with your free Confession, Could I now find a way to disanul the former Match, would you receive my Friend into your Bosom, that's the only means to save your good Name, people will talk else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.p: Brother, let me see how, least my fame will suffer, And I will fix on that.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p:
Sir, A word with you,
He takes Manly aside
I will be plain with you though what I have to say concerns my Sisters innocence. I would advise you to disclaim her, Sir, for by this light, for ought I can hear, she is with Child.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: I will requite your plainness, Sir, in Specie. Were she now Teeming with a litter of seven; nay did she confirm the miracle of that Lady who brought three hundred sixty five at once, I would not quit her cause, I would not loose the money I have long suffer'd for; but knew I how to compass that, and then be rid of her, she should to grass to Night.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Will you compound, and take one half?

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: You tempt me shrewdly, how shall I be secur'd of it?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: It shall be paid you instantly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: 'Tis done then, I'le to travail again; Come give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: I, with it pawn my Faith to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Man.
sp.p: Me thinks, I have driven a very good Aside. Bargain now I shall be rid of a Skittish Jade, and have money to boot. Farwell Matrimony, if ever I be hamper'd in that noose again, let me be choakt with it!

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p:
Cozen your pardon, heark thee Haz.
Salutes Isbel and takes Haz. aside.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Now your pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: What think'st thou of my Sister? how dost like her?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Faith I like her very well.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: What if I made a Match betwixt you two?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Faith I believe one of us would be content to forfeit our earnest, thou hast not a mind to have her hang'd hast thou?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: No certainly, but if I could lay level at the troublesome fences of the Law, what wouldst thou say?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'd say thou wert an excellent Pioneer.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Wouldst marry her?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Yes Fait, for we have both had the best tryal of liking one another, 'tis true I have had her before hand but that's but being my own Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What mean these Whispers?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Sir they concern you much, you must have another Son in Law.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Where must I find him?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: In this Gentleman—Manly (whatever was pretended to, he never enjoy'd my Sister, till last night she was a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'le be sworn she was for Mr. Manly.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Then take your choice, there is a Marriage without Consummation; here's a Consummation without a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: If Manly be contented, I am; for that way which renders my Child an honest Woman.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Sir, he must be contended; He has been above seven years away beyond Sea, and has never Writ her word he was alive; so that in Law the Marriage is void.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Then take her hand she's yours by my Consent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Man.
sp.p: And what is more, by mine. This way my honours safe, but by the other nothing but discontents and endless quarrels could have insu'd. I hope Sir, you will not judge the worse of my Vertue by what has past between us.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I was in fault not you, but 'twas a fault, so fortunate, that I can ne'r repent it; pardon me for what is past, and for the future all my wild follies and debaucheries I'le leave and place my happiness alone in you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: And to encourage your conversion I'le give you Twenty thousand pounds with her, and five times as much that I have in store for you Son.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Thomas you look as if your mouth were big with some request or other.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Me thinks he simpers as if he had a mind to be Married to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Truly Sir you read my Thoughts, for I am as they say, a young beginner, and fain would save the Charges of a Dinner.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Thank your Worships. Isbel set back your appetite some Four and Twenty hours, and then you shall have your belly full.

sp.speaker: Isb.
sp.p: 'Tis a great matter to forbear so long, when a Womans Stomack's up, but I'le endeavour.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Send for a Noise of Fidlers quickly.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I mean to daunce this month without Cessation,
And to be drunk as at a Coronation. Exit omnia:

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: TWice lately have you Grac'd our House before;
For Loves sake, Gallants, give us this bout more.
'Tis all we ask, you've reason kind to be,
When we're so moderate to desire but Three.
Cou'd you deny the Dear that thus shou'd woo
My heart, you've pleas'd your self, now please me too.
Two damn'd ill Playes, your favour has o'repast;
We keep our Loving kindness for the last.
When we grow eager 'twould show rude to scoff,
And to shrink from us with a dry come off.
You see what shift we make to meet again,
To Act with raw Boyes, is Loving without Men.
What will not poor forsaken Women try,
When Man's not near, the Signior must supply.
Excuse our Play; we dare not hope its taking,
We're told of a fine House, and Clothes a making.
And these hir'd Signiors when we meet together,
May then wear Sattin, though they now wear Leather.
